#Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection #Total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage

trans-unit.target: Deterioro de la función ventricular izquierda

Subvalvular stenosis is caused by a diaphragm-like membrane. The stenosis is clinically manifested like any other form of aortic stenosis but is often associated with some aortic insufficiency
Arteriosclerosis occuring at an age that is younger than usual
Complete heart block with narrow QRS complexes
trans-unit.target: Bloqueo cardíaco completo con complejos qrs estrechos

trans-unit.source: Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metatarsal bones

Interphalangeal joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in the interphalangeal joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity

trans-unit.target: Aplasia de la musculatura de la pared abdominal

trans-unit.source: The occurrence of the full-thickness tear (perforation) of the wall of the esophagus
Cyst-like space not lined by epithelium and contained within the pancreas. Pancreatic pseudocysts are often associated with pancreatitis
Watery voluminous diarrhea resulting from an imbalance between ion and water secretion and absorption
The presence of cyst of the intrahepatic bile duct

Leukoplakia is a precancerous dermatosis of mucous membranes analogous Leukoplakia is basically a chronic inflammatory hypertrophy in which anaplasia and malignant dyskeratosis may develop and subsequently advance to an invasive squamous cell cancer. The clinical diagnosis of primary anal leukoplakia is indicated by single or multiple slightly raised,irregular, marginated, grayish-white keratinized' patches in the anal canal. Tissue biopsy is necessary for confirmation
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition lesions in the pancreas
Blockage or impairment of the normal flow of the contents of the intestine towards the anal canal
Increased susceptibility to Giardia lamblia infection of the intestine, as manifested by a medical history of multiple episodes of Giardia lamblia intestinal infection
The presence of a fistula (abnormal tunnel) between the anal canal and the perineum
Absence of gastric intrinsic factor, which is normally produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, and is required for the absorption of vitamin B12
The presence of multiple diverticula of the intestine
A collection of pus in the area of the rectum
Accumulation of cell free, noninflammatony fluid within the wall of the intestinal tract producing uniform thickening of the mucosal folds
Presence of multiple adenomatous polyps in the colon
#Multiple adenomatous colon polyps #Multiple colonic adenomatous polyps
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the pancreas
The presence of a hypoplastic gallbladder
A developmental defect resulting in abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the jejunum
A form of chronic pancreatitis that is characterized by calcification
The presence of degenerative changes of the liver
A congenital defect characterized by the lack of ganglion cells in the entire intestine, i.e., the aganglionic segment comprises the entire large and small bowel
Atresia in the extrahepatic bile duct
Failure to form of portions of the abdominal musculature
A type of gastritis characterized by excessive proliferation of the gastric mucosa and diffuse thickening of the gastric mucosal folds

trans-unit.source: The presence of inflammation of the gastric mucous membrane

trans-unit.target: Parto prematuro debido a insuficiencia cervical o fragilidad de membranas

Pseudocoarctation is a congenital anomaly of kinking, or buckling, of the aorta without a pressure gradient across the lesion. It is characterized by elongation and kinking of the aorta at the level of the ligamentum arteriosum

trans-unit.target: Defecto del canal atrioventricular con aorta ventricular derecha y atresia pulmonar

Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the carotid arteries
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the arch of aorta
Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a cerebral vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow
The presence of a capillary hemangiomas, which are hemangiomas with small endothelial spaces
A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) affecting large arteries such as the aorta and branches of the aorta

trans-unit.target: Fibrosis de la íntima aterial pulmonar

Unilateral overgrowth of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin
#Enlargement of half of face #Facial hemihypertophy #Hemifacial enlargement #Hypertrophy of half of face #Increase in size of half of face #Overgrowth of half of face

Any abnormality of the carotid arteries, including the common carotid artery and its' arterial branches
Inspiratory stridor is a high pitched sound upon inspiration that is generally related to laryngeal abnormalities

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the physiological functioning of B cells

Increased susceptibility to protozoan infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of protozoan infection
Depletion of components of the alternative complement pathway
trans-unit.target: Agotamiento de los componentes de la vía alternativa del complemento

Recurrent infections by bacteria of the genus Neisseria, including N. meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis)

At birth, newborns are endowed with maternal antibodies. IgG production normally begins at the age of two months. A delay in recovery from this physiological hypogammaglobulinemia between the 3rd and the 6th month of life, and of recovery period between 18 and 36 months defines transient newborn hypogammaglobulinemia

trans-unit.target: Alteración de la función de células T

trans-unit.source: Recurrent infections in infancy and early childhood
trans-unit.target: Infecciones recurrentes en la infancia y la niñez temprana

trans-unit.target: Persistencia de la sutura coronal no osificada

trans-unit.source: The presence of a coronal suture (the cranial suture that separates the frontal and parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed

Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal
An increase in bone density affecting the calvaria (roof of the skull)

trans-unit.target: Disminución de la osificación del base del cráneo

Normally, the posterior and lateral fontanelles are obliterated by about six months after birth, the anterior fontanelle closes by about the middle of the second year. This term refers to the situation in which the fontanelles close at an inappropriately early time point

#early closure of the bregma sutures #early closure of the cranial sutures #early closure of the fontanelles #Obliterated fontanelles #premature closure of the bregma sutures #premature closure of the cranial sutures
The presence of calcium deposition in the falx cerebri
Abnormally increased density of craniofacial bone tissue
Excessive growth (overgrowth) of the facial bones, that is of the facial skeleton
#Enlargment of the facial bones #Hyperostosis of facial bones #Hypertrophy of the facial bones #Increase in size of the facial bones #Overgrowth of the facial bones

#acquired microcephaly #Deceleration of head growth #development of small head that was not present at birth #Microcephaly, acquired #Microcephaly, postnatal #Postnatal deceleration of head circumference #postnatal microcephaly

#little cranial sutures #little fontanelle #microfontanelle #small bregma sutures #small cranial sutures

trans-unit.target: Sutura metópica abierta hasta la raíz nasal

trans-unit.source: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone in infants and usually fuses by the age of six years. The suture runs from the bregma (the point on the skull at which the coronal suture is intersected perpendicularly by the sagittal suture) to the nasion or nasal root. This term applies if the suture is widely patent from bregma to nasal root
Midline skin dimples over anterior/posterior fontanelles
trans-unit.target: Hoyuelos en la línea media sobre las fontanelas anterior / posterior
Aumento de la fragilidad osmótica de los glóbulos rojos

trans-unit.source: #Increased erythrocyte osmotic fragility #Increased red cell fragility
A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased proliferation of the granulocytic cell line without the loss of their capacity to differentiate

Normal adult hemoglobin is composed of two chains each of alpha and beta globin. Hb Barts (Hemoglobin Barts) is a tetramer with four gamma globin chains, and is essentially pathognomonic for one or another form of alpha thalassemia. Hb Barts has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, resulting in almost no oxygen delivery to the tissues
A malignant monoclonal gammopathy characterized by a high level of an IgM monoclonal protein
A transient reduction in the number of erythroblasts in the circulation
Anemia characterized by abnormal intracellular inclusions, composed of denatured hemoglobin, found on the membrane of red blood cells

trans-unit.target: Alteración de la capacidad de los neutrófilos para eliminar los estafilococos

trans-unit.source: Increased megakaryocyte number, i.e., of platelet precursor cells, present in the bone marrow
A type of T-cell lymphoma in which cancerous T-cells may present in the blood (leukemia), lymph nodes (lymphoma), skin or in multiple areas
Larger than normal size of erythrocytes

A chronic form of disseminated intravascular coagulation in which a persistent weak or intermittent activating stimulus is present and destruction and production of coagulation factors and platelets are balanced

Disseminated intravascular coagulation is characterized by the widespread activation of coagulation, which results in the intravascular formation of fibrin and ultimately thrombotic occlusion of small and midsize vessels
A type of sideroblastic anemia that is alleviated by pyridoxine (vitamin B-6) treatment
Leukemia associated with hyperplasia of the lymphoid tissues and increased numbers of circulating malignant lymphocytes and lymphoblasts

trans-unit.target: Disminución de la actividad del quininógeno

trans-unit.source: Reduction in the amount of kininogen, which functions as a cofactor in the contact phase of the intrinsic blood coagulation cascade
#Fitzgerald factor deficiency #Kininogen deficiency #Williams factor deficiency #Williams-Fitzgerald-Flaujeac factor deficiency
A reduced number of hematopoietic cells present in the bone marrow
#Bone marrow failure #Bone marrow hypoplasia #Hypoplastic bone marrow

A type of actue leukemia with features characteristic of both the myeloid and lymphoid lineages. These leukemias are for this reason are designated mixed-lineage, hybrid or biphenotypic acute leukemias
A form of hemolytic anemia that can be triggered by exertion

trans-unit.target: Disminución del volumen medio de las plaquetas

trans-unit.source: Average platelet volume below the lower limit of the normal reference interval

trans-unit.target: Linfoma / leucemia linfocítica crónica de células T

Congenital onset of a marked decrease in the number of granulocytes

trans-unit.target: Tiempo de coagulación de sangre total prolongado

trans-unit.source: An abnormal prolongation (delay) in the time required by whole blood to produce a visible clot

trans-unit.target: Disminución de la actividad de la proteína C

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein C. Protein C is activated to protein Ca by thrombin bound to thrombomodulin. Activated protein C degrades factors VIIIa and Va

trans-unit.target: Aumento de la resistencia osmótica de los glóbulos rojos

trans-unit.source: Proliferation (excess production) of hemopoietically active tissue or of tissue which has embryonic hemopoietic potential
A form of neutropenia with congenital onset

A chronic lymphocytic/lymphatic/lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is a neoplastic disease characterized by proliferation and accumulation (blood, marrow and lymphoid organs) of morphologically mature but immunologically dysfunctional lymphocytes. A CLL is always a B-cell lymphocytic leukemia as there are no reports of cases of T-cell lymphocytic leukemias

The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone of the skull in infants and children and generally undergoes fusion by the age of six. A persistent frontal suture is referred to as a "metopic suture"
An abnormality of the zygomatic arch, also known as the cheek bone

Normal hemoglobin synthesis is characterized by production of equal amounts of alpha and beta globins. This term refers to a deviation from this pattern and is the main characteristic of the various forms of thalassemia
Abnormality of bone marrow cell morphology
trans-unit.target: Alteración de la morfología celular de la médula ósea

trans-unit.source: An anomaly of the form or number of cells in the bone marrow
#Anomaly of the bone marrow cells #Bone marrow disease
The presence of many cysts in the kidney

trans-unit.source: A reduction in the count of nephrons per kidney
A lack of differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging
#Absent renal corticomedullary differentiation #Loss of corticomedullary differentiation

trans-unit.target: Reducción de la diferenciación cortico-medular renal

trans-unit.source: Reduced differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging
High urine magnesium in the presence of hypomagnesemia

trans-unit.target: Aumento de la reabsorción tubular renal de fosfato
Disminución de la excreción de fosfato tubular renal

trans-unit.target: Alteración de la reabsorción de cloruro

trans-unit.source: A duplication of the renal pelvis

trans-unit.target: Desintegración de la membrana tubular basal

trans-unit.source: DIsruption and breaking up of the basement membrane of the tubules of the kidney

trans-unit.source: A focal type of palmoplantar keratoderma in whichonly certain areas of the palms and soles are affected

trans-unit.source: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin in a butterfly midface distribution

Large cafe-au-lait macules with irregular margins
trans-unit.target: Manchas café con leche con bordes irregulares

trans-unit.source: Large hypermelanotic macules with jagged borders
The presence of a bilobed gallbladder, related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium
Absence or underdevelopment of the femur

Hyperconvexity of the thoracolumbar spine producing a rounded or humped appearance
The ability of the interphalangeal joints to move beyond their normal range of motion
Increased cross-section (diameter) of the long bones. Note that widening may primarily affect specific regions of long bones (e.g., diaphysis or metaphysis), but this should be coded separately

An enchondroma is a benign growth of cartilage that develops within the medullary cavity of bone. Enchondromatosis refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas, and this term refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas within the medulla of metaphyseal bone. Radiographically an enchondroma presents a an oval, linear, or pyramidal osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with well defined margins
An abnormality of skeletal development characterized by a disturbance of the metaphysis and its histological structure with relatively normal epiphyses and vertebrae

Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal

trans-unit.source: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
trans-unit.target: Deformidades de los dedos de la mano en cuello de cisne

trans-unit.source: A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke

The term proximal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the proximal interphalangeal finger creases

Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as acute if there is onset of encephalopathy within 8 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver
A diffuse form of hepatic steatosis
Decreased mitochondrial complex III activity in liver tissue
trans-unit.target: Disminución de la actividad mitocondrial del complejo iii en el tejido hepático

trans-unit.source: Decreased activity of complex II Of the mitochondrion in the liver
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition in the liver

trans-unit.target: Acumulación de lípidos en los hepatocitos

trans-unit.source: Inflammation of the liver due to infection with a virus

trans-unit.target: Malformación de la placa ductal hepática

Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants
Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule
Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver
trans-unit.target: Depleción del adn mitocondrial en el hígado

trans-unit.source: An abnormal reduction in the number of mitochondria in hepatocytes

trans-unit.target: Episodios similares al sindrome de Reye

trans-unit.source: The two portions of the clavicle (corresponding to the two primary ossification centers of the clavicle) are connected by a fibrous bridge that is contiguous with the periosteum, and a synovial membrane develops, resulting in a clavicle with a bipartite appearance radiographically. Congenital pseudarthrosis of the clavicle generally presents as a painless mass or swelling over the clavicle
An abnormally straight configuration of the clavicle, a tubular bone which normally is doubly curved

trans-unit.target: Tórax inferior en forma de campana

trans-unit.source: Lack of development of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus

trans-unit.source: Irregular surface of the normally relatively smooth border between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum
Early ossification of the costochondral junction, which is the joint between the ribs and costal cartilage in the front of the rib cage
Underdevelopment of the middle portion of the clavicle
A larger than usual distance between the left and right nipple
Decreased number of sternal ossification centers
trans-unit.target: Disminución del número de centros de osificación esternal

trans-unit.source: A less than normal number of sternal ossification centers. The sternum is initially formed from bilateral sternal plates that chondrify and begin to fuse with ribs at 10 weeks gestational age. Ossification starts in the manubrium and upper part of the sternal body at the 6th month, in the middle of the sternal body at the 7th month, in the lower part of the body during the 1st postnatal year and in the xiphoid process between years 5 and 18. The number of ossification centers vary up to six, and it is the ossification centers that are visualized by prenatal ultrasound. This term describes a reduction in the number of ossification centers compared with age-related norms

trans-unit.target: Ausencia intraútero de osificación de los huesos torácicos

trans-unit.source: Lack of formation and mineralization of the ribs in utero

trans-unit.target: Calcificaciones puntiformes anteriores en las costillas

trans-unit.source: Deposition of calcium salts in point-like foci within the anterior portion of one or more ribs
Abnormal increase in density of the tissue at the costochondral junctions
Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal
Lack of formation of mineralized bony tissue of the sternum

trans-unit.target: Hipoplasia de los segmentos distales de la escápula

Osteosclerosis of ribs (increased density related to increased bone mass)
Developmental defect resulting in congenital absence of the middle portion of the clavicle
More than one fracture of the ribs

trans-unit.target: Fusión de los centros de osificación esternales

trans-unit.source: Abnormally reduced diameter (cross section) of the clavicles

Increased time for the complex comprised of the Q wave, R wave, and S wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).. In adults, normal values are 0.06 - 0.10 sec

Inflammation of the coronary arteries involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells

Premature ventricular contractions (PVC) or ventricular extrasystoles are premature contractions of the heart that arise in response to an impulse in the ventricles rather than the normal impulse from the sinoatrial (SA) node
An abnormality of filling of a ventricle with blood during diastole

Acute occurrence of a dissection (tear within the tunica intima and entry of blood into the tunica media) of a coronary artery without an obvious triggering factor

trans-unit.source: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a malignant tumor of squamous epithelium
Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
trans-unit.target: Carcinoma de células transicionales de la vejiga

trans-unit.source: The presence of a carcinoma of the urinary bladder with origin in a transitional epithelial cell
A malignant neoplasm of the adrenal cortex that may produce hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, or testosterone
Pheochromocytoma originating from the adrenal medulla
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the stomach
The presence of leiomyosarcoma of the skin
The presence of a malignant neoplasm of the genital system
The presence of a carcinoma in the renal pelvis
A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells

trans-unit.target: Adenoma hipofisario de células secretoras de prolactina

trans-unit.source: A type of pituitary adenoma originating in prolactin secreting cells. This kind of adenoma is characterized by overproduction of prolactin, and may cause loss of menstrual periods and breast milk production in women

A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the duodenum
A benign renal neoplasm composed of fat, vascular, and smooth muscle elements
The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the ovary
A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton
A non-malignant neoplasm of the genitourinary system
A malignancy of the parathyroid glands. Parathyroid carcinoma usually secretes parathyroid hormone, leading to hyperparathyroidism
A kind of thyroid adenoma characterized by the presence of oxyphil cells
Muscular dystrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle (the hips and shoulders)
Frequent menses; menstrual cycles lasting less than 21 days
Median longitudinal ear length greater than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear
Median longitudinal ear length less than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear
Folds or ridges within the concha that are distinct from the crus helix
Focal absence of the external ear
Absence of a localized portion of the ear that cannot be described by a more precise term (e.g., absent ear lobe)
Increased vertical distance from the vermillion border of the lower lip to the inferior-most point of the chin
Vertical crease fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin with the face at rest
Loss of ability to walk in first decade
trans-unit.target: Pérdida de la capacidad para caminar en la primera década

trans-unit.source: Prolonged/excessive menses and bleeding at irregular intervals

trans-unit.target: Alteración de las células del cuerno anterior de la médula espinal

trans-unit.source: Any anomaly of the anterior horn cell
#Abnormality of the anterior horn cell #Abnormality of the anterior horn cells #Anomaly of the anterior horn cells #Anterior horn cell disease

trans-unit.target: Estancamiento del desarrollo al inicio de cuadro convulsivo

The occurrence of repeated episodes of generalized muscular hypotonia
Wasting (atrophy) of the vermis of cerebellum
#Atrophy of cerebellar vermis #Atrophy of the cerebellar vermis

trans-unit.target: Deterioro o pérdida de la propiocepción distal

trans-unit.source: A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position occuring at distal joints

trans-unit.target: Retraso en el lenguaje expresivo grave

trans-unit.source: A type of holoprosencephaly characterized by the presence of a single ventricle and no separation of the cerebral hemisphere. The single midline ventricle is often greatly enlarged

Dysplasia and dysgenesis of the corpus callosum are nonspecific descriptions that imply defective development of the corpus callosum. The term dysplasia is applied when the morphology of the corpus callosum is altered as a congenital trait. For instance, the corpus callosum may be hump-shaped, kinked, or a striped corpus callosum that lacks an anatomically distinct genu and splenium
#Dysgenesis of corpus callosum #Dysplasia of corpus callosum
A type of gliosis that occurs in the vicinity of injured neurons

#Cell loss and gliosis in the basal ganglia

trans-unit.target: Pérdida de células de Purkinje del vermis cerebeloso

trans-unit.source: Progressive impairment of function of motor axons with muscle weakness, atrophy, and cramps. The deficits are length-dependent, meaning that muscles innervated by the longest nerves are affected first, so that for instance the arms are affected at a later age than the onset of deficits involving the lower leg
The formation of small cavities in the tissue of the basal ganglia

trans-unit.target: Parálisis del iv par craneal o nervio troclear

Bilateral impairment of the function of the cranial nerves 9-12, which control musculature involved in eating, swallowing, and speech. #Muscle atrophy, proximal #Proximal muscle atrophy #Proximal muscle wasting #Symmetric proximal muscular atrophy #Symmetrical, proximal limb muscle atrophy

trans-unit.source: A form of gray matter heterotopia were the mislocalized gray matter is typically located periventricularly, also sometimes called subependymal heterotopia. Periventricular means beside the ventricles. This is by far the most common location for heterotopia. Subependymal heterotopia present in a wide array of variations. There can be a small single node or a large number of nodes, can exist on either or both sides of the brain at any point along the higher ventricle margins, can be small or large, single or multiple, and can form a small node or a large wavy or curved mass
#Periventricular neuronal heterotopia #Subependymal gray matter heterotopia #Subependymal neuronal heterotopia

An abnormality of somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP), i.e., of the electrical signals of sensation going from the body to the brain in response to a defined stimulus. Recording electrodes are placed over the scalp, spine, and peripheral nerves proximal to the stimulation site. Clinical studies generally use electrical stimulation of peripheral nerves to elicit potentials. SSEP testing determines whether peripheral sensory nerves are able to transmit sensory information like pain, temperature, and touch to the brain. Abnormal SSEPs can result from dysfunction at the level of the peripheral nerve, plexus, spinal root, spinal cord, brain stem, thalamocortical projections, or primary somatosensory cortex
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the gastrointestinal tract
#Gastrointestinal tract neoplasia #Gastrointestinal tract neoplasm #Gastrointestinal tract tumor
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the genitourinary system
#Genitourinary tract neoplasia #Genitourinary tract neoplasm #Genitourinary tract tumors

trans-unit.source: An ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin that presents at birth or shortly thereafter with generalized, erythema, blistering, erosions, and peeling. In the subsequent months, erythema and blistering improves but patients go on to develop hyperkeratotic scaling that is especially prominent along the joint flexures, neck, hands and feet
An abnormality of dermatoglyphs (fingerprints), which are present on fingers, palms, toes, and soles

The term collodion baby applies to newborns who appear to have an extra layer of skin (known as a collodion membrane) that has a collodion-like quality. It is a descriptive term, not a specific diagnosis or disorder (as such, it is a syndrome). Affected babies are born in a collodion membrane, a shiny waxy outer layer to the skin. This is shed 10-14 days after birth, revealing the main symptom of the disease, extensive scaling of the skin caused by hyperkeratosis. With increasing age, the scaling tends to be concentrated around joints in areas such as the groin, the armpits, the inside of the elbow and the neck. The scales often tile the skin and may resemble fish scales

#Collodion baby #Congenital lamellar ichthyosis #Congenital non-bullous ichthyosis #Ichthyosis lammellaris #Ichthyosis, congenital, nonblistering #Nonbullous congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma #Nonbullous congenital ichthyosis

trans-unit.source: A severe degree of photosensitivity of the skin
Presence of a cutaneous lipoma on the forehead
Absent pigmentation of the ventral chest
Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the anterior chest
Piebaldism is characterized by stable and persistent, well-circumscribed depigmented patches present at birth affecting the skin of the face, trunk, and extremities in a symmetrical distribution

trans-unit.source: The presence of six or more cafe-au-lait spots

trans-unit.target: Bucle radial dermatoglífico en dedo índice

trans-unit.source: Hyperkeratosis lenticularis perstans (HLP), also known as Flegel disease, is a keratinization abnormality characterized by small, asymptomatic erythematous papules that leave characteristic punctate bleeding when they become detached. The lesions generally occur symmetrically along the top of the foot and on the legs, appearing more rarely on the arms, forearms, palms, and soles, and even on the oral mucosa

trans-unit.target: Fragilidad de la piel con ampollas que no dejan cicatriz
Telangiectasias que dan un aspecto de mármol a la piel

trans-unit.source: Increased pigmentation of the skin with a netlike (reticular) pattern

trans-unit.target: Aplasia cutis congénita en el tronco o las extremidades

trans-unit.source: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the trunk or the limbs

trans-unit.target: Aplasia cutis congénita en el área parietal posterior

trans-unit.source: Aplasia/Hypoplastia of the eccrine sweat glands
trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de las glándulas sudoríparas ecrinas

trans-unit.source: Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the eccrine sweat glands
The presence of multiple subcutaneous lipoma that cause pain
The distal and proximal transverse palmar creases are merged into a single transverse palmar crease on both hands

trans-unit.target: Hemangioma capilar de la línea media de la cara
Pecas en las áreas expuestas al sol
Arrugamiento excesivo de la piel palmar

trans-unit.source: Spinous keratoses of palms and soles
trans-unit.target: Queratosis espinosas de palmas y plantas

trans-unit.source: Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the neck. This is one of the most common birthmarks and present in approximately 25% of all newborns

trans-unit.target: Pigmentación de la piel reticulada fina

The presence of leiomyoma of the skin

trans-unit.target: Anomalías de pigmentación de la piel expuesta al sol

trans-unit.source: A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of both eyes

trans-unit.target: Neuropatía óptica isquémica anterior no arterítica

trans-unit.source: An acute condition characterized by sudden visual loss (usually discovered in the morning), optic disc edema at onset, optic disc-related visual field defects. Nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy can be associated with flame hemorrhages on the swollen disc or nearby neuroretinal layer, and sometimes with nearby cotton-wool exudates
A form of colorblindness in which only two of the three fundamental colors can be distinguished due to a lack of one of the retinal cone pigments
A nonprogressive (i.e., stationary) form of difficulties with night blindness with congenital onset

#Congenital night blindness #Night blindness, congenital #Night blindness, congenital stationary #Night blindness, congenital stationary, complete #Night blindness, stationary #Static congenital hemeralopia

trans-unit.target: Desprendimiento periférico de retina por tracción

trans-unit.source: Lack of eyelashes on the lower lid

trans-unit.target: Anomalía congénita de los músculos extraoculares

trans-unit.source: Congenital abnormality of the extraocular muscles
A type of cataract with punctate opacities of the lens
Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
trans-unit.target: Hipertrofia congénita del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

trans-unit.source: Sharply demarcated, congenital hyperpigmentation of thr retinal pigment epithelium
Eversion of lateral third of lower eyelids
trans-unit.target: Eversión del tercio lateral del párpado inferior

trans-unit.source: A congenital defect of development characterized by absence of the lacrimal gland
Opacity of the entire lens nucleus
#Central blurring of vision #Central visual loss #Decreased central vision #Decreased visual acuity #Poor visual acuity

trans-unit.target: Deterioro del inicio y mantenimiento de la búsqueda visual

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR). The VOR attempts to keep the image stable on the retina. Ideally passive or active head movements in one direction are compensated for by eye movements of equal magnitude
Vitelliform maculopathy is a sharply demarcated lesion caused by the accumulation of material, often lipofuscin in the subretinal space underlying the macula
Narrowing of a tear duct (lacrimal duct)
A functional abnormality of the pupil

trans-unit.target: Ausencia de respuesta de conos y bastones en electroretinograma (ERG)

trans-unit.source: Absence of the combined rod-and-code response on electroretinogram
#Absent cone and rod functions by electroretinogram #Absent cone and rod functions by electroretinogram (ERG) #Absent rod-and cone-mediated responses on ERG

trans-unit.target: Alteración del reflejo pupilar a la luz

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the reflex that controls the diameter of the pupil, in response to the intensity of light that falls on the retina of the eye
Abnormal development (dysgenesis) of the anterior segment of the eye globe. These structures are mainly of mesenchymal origin

#Anterior chamber cleavage defect #Anterior chamber cleavage disorder #Anterior chamber malformation #Anterior chamber mesodermal anomalies #Anterior segment mesencyhmal dysgenesis #Anterior segment ocular dysgenesis
#Abnormal retinal pigmentation #Abnormality of the retinal pigment epithelium #Retinal pigmentary anomaly

trans-unit.target: Movimientos paroxísticos involuntarios de los ojos

trans-unit.source: Sudden-onset episode of abnormal, involuntary eye movements
A developmental defect resulting in congenital absence of the crystalline lens

trans-unit.target: Distrofia corneal en forma de banda

trans-unit.source: A malignant melanoma originating within the eye. The tumor originates from the melanocytes in the uvea (which comprises the iris, ciliary body, and choroid)
A chronic irritative conjunctivitis, which commonly presents with general irritation and redness of the eyes, with a burning, dry, or foreign-body sensation of the eyes

Cornea plana is an abnormally flat shape of the cornea such that the normal protrusion of the cornea from the sclera is missing. The reduced corneal curvature can lead to hyperopia, and a hazy corneal limbus and arcus lipoides may develop at an early age
Presence of multiple aneurysms (sac-like outpouchings) in the blood vessels of the conjunctiva

trans-unit.target: Pérdida de epitelio pigmentario de la retina

trans-unit.source: Wasting of the retinal pigment epithelium
Lack of transparency of the corneal epithelium
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil of congenital onset
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation of the iris
Abnormal development of the choroid and retina
Bone spicule pigmentation of the retina
trans-unit.target: Retinopatía pigmentaria en forma de espículas óseas

trans-unit.source: A term for the pigmented cells within the retina in retinitis pigmentosa because of their resemblance to the nucleated cells within the lacuna of bone
#Bone corpuscle fundus pigmentation #Fundus with peripheral bony spicules #Retinal 'bone corpuscle' pigmentation #Retinal bone corpuscle pigmentation
The presence of a coloboma affecting the iris and the retina
The presence of a coloboma of iris, choroid and retina
Macular dystrophy is a nonspecific term for premature retinal cell aging and cell death, generally confied to the macula in which no clear extrinsic cause is evident
Slitlike anterior chamber angles in children
trans-unit.target: Ángulos de cámara anterior en forma de ranura en niños
Opacidad del estroma de la córnea

trans-unit.source: Reduced transparency of the stroma of cornea
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) that surrounds the central fixation point
Dilatation of small blood vessels of the retina
Increased depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is increased
Underdevelopment of the optic disc, that is of the optic nerve head, where ganglion cell axons exit the eye to form the optic nerve

trans-unit.target: Tortuosidad vascular central de la retina

trans-unit.source: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of retinal blood vessels (arteries, arterioles, veins, venules)
An impairment of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion
#Abnormal visual pursuit #Abnormality of visual tracking #Impairment of visual pursuit
Neovascularization of peripheral and posterior retina
trans-unit.target: Neovascularización de la retina periférica y posterior

trans-unit.source: A type of cataract characterized by punctate, dust-like opacities within the cortical region of the lens
A type of cataract affecting the posterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the Lens capsule
#Posterior subcapsular cataracts #Posterior subcapsular opacities of the lens
Patchy atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium
trans-unit.target: Atrofia irregular del epitelio pigmentario de la retina
Anomalía pigmentaria en moteado de la mácula lútea

trans-unit.source: Mottled (spotted or blotched with different shades) pigmentary abnormality of the macula lutea
A cataract that affects the anterior part of the cortex of the lens
The presence of whitish deposits in the conjunctiva resembling salt. May be related to calcinosis

trans-unit.target: Aumento de la longitud axial del globo ocular

trans-unit.source: Abnormal largeness of the eye with an axial length > 2.5 standard deviations from population mean

The presence of central, fine, whitish granular lesions in the stroma of the cornea. This type of corneal dystrophy is usually asymptomatic and begins in childhood and shows a slow progression. Later in the course, the corneal epithelium and Bowman's layer may be affected. Histologically, the cornea shows a uniform deposition of hyaline material
Complete color blindness, a complete inability to distinguish colors. Affected persons cannot perceive colors, but only shades of gray
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements of equal velocity

The presence of one or more dendritic corneal epithelial ulcers characterized by a treelike branching linear pattern with feathery edges and terminal bulbs. Herpetiform corneal ulcers can be identified by fluorescein staining
A form of uveitis that is not associated with the formation of granulomas
Mottling (Spots or blotches with different shades) of the retinal pigment epithelium
#Focal hypopigmentation of the retinal pigment epithelium #Retinal pigment epithelium irregularity #RPE irregularity #Salt and pepper retinal pigmentation #Salt and pepper retinopathy
Abnormal distribution of retinal arterioles and venules
trans-unit.target: Distribución anormal de las arteriolas y vénulas de la retina

trans-unit.source: A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a horizontal direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal
The presence of distinct colors in the central (pupillary) zone of the iris than in the mid-peripheral (ciliary) zone
Presenile cataract is a kind of cataract that occurs in early adulthood, that is, at an age that is younger than usual
Congenital absence or closure of the opening of the lacrimal punctum
Paralysis of both the extrinsic and intrinsic ocular muscles
Inability to see well at night or in poor light with onset in adulthood

Nonprogressive restriction of movement of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited
A kind of cataract that progresses with age

trans-unit.target: Fisuras palpebrales en forma de S

trans-unit.source: Increased length of the upper eyelashes
Amyloid deposition in the vitreous humor
trans-unit.target: Depósitos amiloides en el humor vítreo
Atenuación de los vasos sanguíneos de la retina

trans-unit.source: Punctate opacification (reduced transparency) of the corneal stroma
Punched out lesions in the pigmented layer of the retina
Horizontal nystagmus dating from or present at birth
Deposition of calcium salts in the retina
Fibrosis of only some of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position

trans-unit.target: Degeneración macular relacionada con la edad

trans-unit.source: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a medical condition which usually affects older adults and results in a loss of vision in the center of the visual field (the macula) because of damage to the retina
The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the choroid. These are generally reddish or orange or can have increased pigmentation maiking them difficult to distinguish from choroidal melanomas

trans-unit.target: Hendidura palpebral con forma de almendra

trans-unit.source: A shape created by an acute downward arching of the upper eyelid and upward arching of the lower eyelid, toward the medial canthus, which gives the outline of the palpebral fissures the configuration of an almond. Thus, the maximum distance between the fissures is offset from, and medial to, the center point
Allergic Conjunctivitis is an allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva
An abnormally slow velocity of horizontal saccadic eye movements
Congenital absence of the extraocular muscles
A type of posterior subcapsular cataract characterized by an iridescent color
Decreased amount of pigmentation of the retina
Failure of attachment of the retina during development
Bleeding within the vitreous compartment of the eye
Chorioretinal atrophy along the retinal veins

This corneal dystrophy affects the posterior limiting membrane of the cornea and is characterized by polymorphous plaques of calcium deposits in the deep stromal layers of the cornea, and occasionally by vesicular lesions of the endothelium and edema of the deep corneal stroma

A type of retinal detachment associated with traction exerted by fibrous or fibrovascular tissue. The fibrous tissue is visible in the vitreous and may be the result of injury, inflammation or neovascularization. If such membranes contract, they pull the sensory retina apart from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium

trans-unit.target: Disminución lenta de la agudeza visual

trans-unit.source: #Decreased visual acuity, slowly progressive #Subacute deterioration of visual acuity
A congenital defect resulting in absence of the lacrimal duct
Anomaly of the visual evoked potentials elicited by a flash stimulus, generally a flash of light subtending an angle of at least 20 degrees of the visual field and presented in a dimly lit room
Congenital abnormal dilation of the pupil on both sides
Regional increase in the width (height) of the lateral eyebrow
Fibrosis of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited

trans-unit.target: Degeneración de la retina en panal

trans-unit.source: A form of monochromacy in which vision is derived from the remaining preserved blue (S) cones and rod photoreceptors
Paralysis of the iris and ciliary apparatus
A form of stapes ankylosis with congenital onset
A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures on one side only
A type of posterior cortical cataract characterized by dense lenticular opacities
Chorioretinal atrophy concentrated around the optic papilla (i.e., the optic nerve head)
Optic atrophy from cranial nerve compression
trans-unit.target: Atrofia óptica por compresión del nervio craneal
Alteración de la pigmentación de la retina

trans-unit.source: #Absence of visual evoked potentials #Non-detectable VEP #Undetectable VEP

A failure of regression of the hyaloid vessel, which supplies the primary vitreous during embryogenesis and normally regresses in the third trimester of pregnancy, leading to a particular form of posterior cataract. This condition is known as Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV)
#Persistent hyperplasia of primary vitreous #Persistent hypertrophic primary vitreous
A congenital cataract in which opacity is limited to layers of the lens external to the nucleus (i.e., the perinuclear region), i.e., between the nuclear and cortical layers of the lens
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the retina
Saccadic undershoot of horizontal saccadic eye movements, i.e., a horizontal saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object

Cerulean cataracts are a kind of congenital cataract having peripheral bluish and white opacifications in concentric layers with occasional central lesions arranged radially. Although the opacities may be observed during fetal development and childhood, usually visual acuity is only mildly reduced until adulthood, when lens extraction is generally necessary
Horizontal nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left

trans-unit.target: Ausencia del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

trans-unit.source: Reduced amplitude of dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram b-wave
An abnormal reduction in the amplitude of the b-wave in the presence of a preserved a-wave
#Electronegative electroretinogram #Electronegative ERG #Electroretinogram: reduced b-wave amplitude #Reduced amplitude of b-wave (ERG) #Reduced rod b-wave (ERG)

trans-unit.target: Oclusión de las arteriolas de la retina

trans-unit.source: Blockage of retinal arteriole, generally associated with interruption of blood flow and oxygen delivery to affected regions of the retina
Decreased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea
Retinal exudate within the retinal tissue itself
Underdevelopment of the stroma of iris
Loss of peripheral vision with retention of central vision, resulting in a constricted circular tunnel-like field of vision

An abnormally reduced response to stimulation of the cornea (by touch, foreign body, blowing air). The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex, normally results in an involuntary blinking of the eyelids
Increased amount of pigmentation in the fovea centralis
Abnormality of macular or foveal pigmentation
Reduced transparency of the peripheral region of the cornea

trans-unit.target: Microaneurismas arteriolares del fondo de ojo central

trans-unit.source: Microscopic aneurysms of the retinal arterioles near the central part of the fundus, visible as small round dark red dots on the retinal surface (not arising from visible vessels) that are by definition less than the diameter of the major optic veins as they cross the optic disc
Partial dislocation of the lens in a superior direction
A type of congenital cataract in which the opacities are confined to a small central area within the embryonic or fetal nuclei of the Iens. The remaining lens is clear
A form of macular degeneration characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the macula
A type of sutural cataract in which the opacity follows the posterior Y suture

A variant of retinitis pigmentosa characterized by areas of choroidal degeneration with pigment migration and bony spicule formation in the macular area. In contrast to more typical forms of RP, this anomaly destroys central vision, leaving peripheral vision intact
Absence or underdevelopment of the lacrimal gland

trans-unit.target: Constricción de las arteriolas de la retina

trans-unit.source: Decreased retinal arteriolar diameters, which may decrease blood flow and slow oxygen delivery to regions of the retina
#Constricted retinal arterioles #Narrow retinal arterioles #Retinal arteriolar narrowing

trans-unit.target: Potenciales visuales evocados (por flash) con latencia alargada
Anomalía de la vasculatura de la retina

trans-unit.source: An arterial or venous retinal vascular anomaly
Abnormality of the vasculature of the eye
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la vasculatura del ojo

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the line of Schwalbe
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la línea de Schwalbe

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the line of Schwalbe
An abnormality of an extraocular muscle
An anomaly of the space between the medial and lateral canthi of the two open eyelids
A wrinkle of retinal tissue projecting outward from the surface of the retina and visible as a line on fundoscopy
Absence or underdevelopment of the iris
Abnormality of the vasculature of the conjunctiva
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la vasculatura de la conjuntiva

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the blood vessels of the conjunctiva
Absence or underdevelopment of the uvea, the pigmented middle layer of the eye consisting of the iris and ciliary body together with the choroid

trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia del fondo de ojo

trans-unit.source: Congenital absence or underdevelopment of the fovea centralis
Aplasia/Hypoplasia affecting the anterior segment of the eye
trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia del segmento anterior del ojo

trans-unit.source: Absence or underdevelopment of the anterior segment of the eye
Absence or underdevelopment of the lens
An abnormality of the skin characterized the presence of excessive amounts of dry surface scales on the skin resulting from an abnormality of keratinization
#Hypertrophic ichthyosis #Ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin #Ichthyotic skin
The presence of one or more bullae on the skin, defined as fluid-filled blisters more than 5 mm in diameter with thin walls
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skin
#Dermatological tumors #Neoplasia of the skin #Skin cancer #Skin tumors #Tumor of the skin
Increased blood pressure during a pregnancy
Virilization (deepening of voice, facial hirsutism and scalp hair loss) with onset during pregnancy (usually towards the end of the first trimester) and regression several months post-partum
An abnormally high concentration of serum conjugated estriol as compared to normal values for gestational-age
The development of Pes cavus that is progressive with age
Reduction in bone mineral density affecting any or all of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones
A developmental abnormality characterized by the absence of the fifth metatarsal bone
#Absent 5th metatarsals #Aplasia of the fifth metatarsal bone
Medial deviation of the great toe owing to a deformity of the great toe joint causing the hallux to deviate medially

trans-unit.target: Hipoplasia de la segunda a la quinta falange media de los dedos de los pies

trans-unit.source: The presence of a fifth metatarsal bone that has not undergone ossification at an age when ossification is usually visible
Abnormality of the fifth metatarsal bone
An anomaly of the fifth metatarsal bone

trans-unit.target: Anquilosis de las pequeñas articulaciones de los pies
Dedos de los pies muy separados

trans-unit.source: An overall widening of the spaces between the digits

trans-unit.target: Desviación medial del segundo dedo del pie

trans-unit.source: Medial deviation of the second toe
Expanded metatarsals with widened medullary cavities
trans-unit.target: Metatarsianos agrandados con cavidades medulares ensanchadas
Retraso en la osificación de los huesos del tarso

trans-unit.source: Delayed maturation and calcification of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones
Plantar crease between first and second toes
trans-unit.target: Pliegue plantar entre el primer y segundo dedos del pie

trans-unit.source: The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the skin of sole of foot located between the first and second toe

trans-unit.target: Osificación avanzada de los huesos del tarso

trans-unit.source: Precocious (accelerated) maturation and calcification of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones

trans-unit.target: Dedo gordo del pie ancho en su parte distal
Esclerosis endosteal de la diáfisis del metatarso

trans-unit.source: Osteosclerosis of the endosteal surface of the diaphyses (shafts) of the metatarsal bones

trans-unit.target: Clinodactilia del tercer dedo del pie

trans-unit.source: Bending or curvature of a third toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe)

trans-unit.target: Limitación de flexión de los dedos del pie

trans-unit.source: Limitation of the ability to bend the toes
Synostosis of the calcaneus with the navicular bone
A congenital deformity characterized by a dorsiflexed, inverted, and adducted foot, i.e., a combination of talipes calcaneus and talipes varus
A two-part calcaneus, a finding that probably results from delayed coalescence of two primary calcaneal centers of ossification

#Delayed coalescence of bipartite calcanei #Delayed coalescence of calcaneal ossification centers #Delayed fusion of bipartite calcanei #Double calcaneal ossification center #Extra calcaneal ossification center
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more tarsal bones
Medial rotation of the medial malleolus
Defective ossification in an irregular pattern of the seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones

Abnormal plantar flexion of the calcaneus relative to the longitudinal axis of the tibia. This results in the angle between the long axis of the tibia and the long axis of the heel bone (calcaneus) being greater than 90 degrees

trans-unit.target: Dislocación de los dedos del pie
Retraso en la osificación del calcáneo

trans-unit.source: Delayed maturation and calcification of the calcaneus

trans-unit.target: Aplanamiento de la cúpula del astrágalo
Alteración de la agregación plaquetaria inducida por la epinefrina

trans-unit.source: Abnormal response to epinephrine as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of epinephrine
Elevations of the levels of SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) and SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase) that occur during infections
Increased time to coagulation in the prothrombin time test, which is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation
Episodes of muscle weakness associated with reduced levels of potassium in the blood
Excessive amounts of mucopolysaccharide in the urine
Hyperapobetalipoproteinemia is defined as the combination of a normal low density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the face of an increased LDL apolipoprotein B (apoB) protein
A decrease in alkaline phosphatase activity measured within leukocytes below detectable levels
An increased concentration of ammonia in the blood not associated with symptoms such as encephalopathy

trans-unit.target: Déficit del nivel de cortisol circulante

trans-unit.source: Abnormally reduced concentration of cortisol in the blood
#Low to undetectable plasma cortisol #Plasma cortisol low

trans-unit.target: Disminución de las células T auxiliares circulantes

trans-unit.source: Reduced numbers of helper T cells

trans-unit.target: Disminución de la actividad de la beta-galactosidasa

trans-unit.source: Abnormally decreased rate of beta-galactosidase activity
#Beta-galactosidase deficiency in fibroblasts and white blood cells #Beta-galactosidase-1 deficiency #Decreased beta-galactosidase activity (leukocyte, fibroblast, plasma)
Very long chain fatty acid accumulation
trans-unit.target: Acumulación de ácidos grasos de cadena muy larga
Disminución de la actividad del factor VII

trans-unit.source: Reduced activity of coagulation factor VII. Factor VII is part of the extrinsic coagulation pathway, which is initiated at the site of injury in response to the release of tissue factor (fIII). Tissue factor and activated factor VII catalyze the activation of factor X
An abnormal reduction in the Arden ratio, which is the raio between the light peak and the dark trough of the smoothed (physiologic) EOG record
#Mildly increased creatine kinase #Mildly increased serum creatine kinase #Moderately increased serum creatine kinase
An absence of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood
The onset of puberty before the age of 9 years in boys
The presence of large polyhedral cells with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei in the adrenal cortex
No secondary sexual characteristics are present at puberty
The congenital absence of the thyroid gland

trans-unit.target: Adenomas pancreático de células beta múltiple

trans-unit.source: The presence of multiple pancreatic islet cell adenomas
Deficiency of parathyroid hormone with congenital onset
A type of hyperparathyroidism caused by a primary abnormality of the parathyroid glands (e.g., adenoma, carcinoma, hyperplasia). Primary hyperparathyroidism is associated with hyercalcemia
A reduced ability to secrete prolactin, a protein hormone that is secreted by lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary and that stimulates mammary gland development and milk production
Precocious puberty with Sertoli cell tumor
trans-unit.target: Pubertad precoz con tumor de células de Sertoli

trans-unit.source: Ketosis-resistant diabetes is a synonym for type II diabetes. This term thus refers to a form of type II diabetes in which patients are dependent on insulin
Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands as a result of a primary defect in the glands themselves
Premature ovarian failure is characterized by amenorrhea, hypoestrogenism, and elevated serum gonadotropin levels in women younger than 40 years

A reduced ability to secrete gonadotropins, which are protein hormones secreted by gonadotrope cells of the anterior pituitary gland, including the hormones follitropin (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)
Abnormal development of the adrenal gland

The ossification process begins in the center of the body about the ninth week, and extends toward either extremity. The center for the base of the first metatarsal appears about the third year, and the centers for the heads of the other bones between the fifth and eighth years. They join the bodies between the eighteenth and twentieth years

Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation. Pulsatile tinnitus may be associated with vascular abnormalities such as arterioevenous shunts or glomus tumors or the jugular vein, arterial bruits related to a high-riding carotid artery (close to the auditory areas) or carotid stenosis, or venous abnormalities such as a dehiscent jugular bulb or to hypertension. Finally, in some patients, mechanical abnormalities such a spatulous eustachian tubes, palatomyoclonus (small spasms of muscles in the soft palate area), or idiopathic stapedial muscle spasm may represent the underlying cause of pulsatile tinnitus
A developmental anomaly of the ureter

Slow or limited growth after birth

Disproportionate shortening of the proximal segment of limbs (i.e. the femur and humerus)
#Rhizomelic dwarfism #Rhizomelic limb shortening #Rhizomelic short limbs #Rhizomelic short stature #Rhizomelic shortening #Short stature, rhizomelic #Symmetrical rhizomelic limb shortening

trans-unit.target: Talla baja letal con extremidades cortas
Obesidad troncal de inicio en la infancia

trans-unit.source: Truncal obesity with onset during childhood, defined as between 2 and 10 years of age

trans-unit.target: Talla baja neonatal con miembros cortos

trans-unit.source: A type of short-limbed dwarfism that is manifest beginning in the neonatal period

#Dwarfism, neonatal short-limbed #Neonatal short-limbed dwarfism #Short limb dwarfism recognizable at birth #Short-limb dwarfism identifiable at birth #Short-limb dwarfism identifiable neonatally #Short-limbed dwarfism identifiable at birth

trans-unit.target: Talla baja con tronco corto de inicio infantil

trans-unit.source: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in childhood
#Disproportionate short stature (short trunk), identifiable in childhood #Short-trunk dwarfism identifiable during childhood
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period and affecting the entire musculature
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk
Muscular atrophy of distal leg muscles
#Lower leg amyotrophy #Lower limb atrophy #Lower limb muscle hypotrophy #Muscle atrophy, lower limb, distal
Loss of ability to walk in early childhood
trans-unit.target: Pérdida de la capacidad de caminar en la infancia temprana

trans-unit.source: Atrophy of the muscles of the pelvic girdle (also known as hip girdle), i.e., the gluteal muscles, the lateral rotators, the adductors, the psoas major and the iliacus muscle
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in infancy
Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the arms
#Proximal muscle atrophy in upper limbs #Proximal upper limb muscle atrophy
Underdevelopment of muscles of the shoulder

trans-unit.target: Atrofia muscular intrínseca de la mano

trans-unit.source: Atrophy of the intrinsic muscle groups of the hand, comprising the thenar and hypothenar muscles; the interossei muscles; and the lumbrical muscles
Progressive muscular atrophy affecting muscles in the distal portions of the extremities
Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the legs, i.e., of the thigh
#Amyotrophy involving the thigh #Amyotrophy of the thigh musculature #Proximal lower limb muscle atrophy #Thigh muscle atrophy

trans-unit.target: Debilidad muscular distal de extremidad superior

trans-unit.source: Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the arms

trans-unit.target: Hipoplasia del músculo de la pantorrilla

trans-unit.source: Underdevelopment of the muscuklature of the calf
Muscle weakness affecting the tibialis anterior muscle
Muscular atrophy that does not display a progression in severity with time

trans-unit.target: Rigidez muscular inducida por el ejercicio

Muscle hypertrophy of the lower extremities
Muscle hypertrophy primarily affecting the legs
Decreased activity of mitochondrial respiratory chain
trans-unit.target: Disminución de la actividad de la cadena respiratoria mitocondrial

trans-unit.target: Hipertrofia del músculo de la pantorrilla

trans-unit.source: Muscle hypertrophy affecting the calf muscles

Underdevelopment of muscles of the neck
An abnormal increase in the amount of intramuscular fat tissue
Congenital lack, i.e., aplasia of the diaphragm
Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles that attach to the pelvic girdle (the gluteal muscles, the lateral rotators, adductor magnus, adductor brevis, adductor longus, pectineus, and gracilis muscles)

trans-unit.target: Calambres en las piernas inducidos por el ejercicio

An abnormal increase in the amount of intraabdominal fat tissue
Proximal muscle weakness in lower limbs

trans-unit.source: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles of the arms

trans-unit.target: Debilidad muscular de la pared abdominal

trans-unit.source: Decreased strength of the abdominal musculature
The presence of an abnormally increased amount of connective tissue
Underdevelopment of the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is involved in adduction, extension, internal rotation, and transverse extension of the shoulder and assists in movement of the scapula

Weakness of the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot, that is, of the movement of the toes towards the shin. The foot dorsiflexors include the tibialis anterior, the extensor hallucis longus, the extensor digitorum longus, and the peroneus tertius muscles

trans-unit.target: Amiotrofia de la musculatura del tobillo

trans-unit.source: Atrophy of the muscles of the ankle
Severe hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells
Atrophy of the peroneous muscles, peroneus longus (also known as Fibularis longus)' (FMA:22539), Peroneus brevis (also known as fibularis brevis, and Peroneus tertius (also known as fibularis tertius
Muscular atrophy involving the quadriceps muscle
An increased amount of glycogen in muscle tissue

trans-unit.target: Debilidad muscular distal de extremidad inferior

Loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue from upper limbs

Contenido aumentado de lípidos en tejido muscular

trans-unit.source: An abnormal accumulation of lipids in skeletal muscle
#Fat accumulation in muscle fibers #Fat deposits in muscle fibers #Lipid accumulation in skeletal muscle #Muscle lipidosis #Skeletal muscle lipid accumulation
Atrophy of the muscles that are responsible for moving the scapula, which are the levator scapulae, the infraspinatus muscle, the teres major, the teres minor, and the supraspinatus muscle
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk and with onset in infancy
Progressively reduced strength of the distal musculature
#Muscle weakness, distal, progressive #Muscle weakness, progressive, distal
Generalized degenerative changes of the fat tissue
Progressive spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem
Decreased intensity of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed
Lack of strength of the proximal muscles that becomes progressively more severe
Weakness of long finger extensor muscles

trans-unit.source: Midline notch of upper alveolar ridge

trans-unit.source: Increased width of the alveolar ridges
#Hypertrophied alveolar ridge #Overgrowth of alveolar ridge #Thick alveolar ridges #Thickened alveolar ridges
Impairment in the physical production of speech sounds

trans-unit.target: Hipertrofia progresiva de la cresta alveolar

trans-unit.source: Cleft palate of the midline of the palate
A cleft of the lip with overlying mucous membrane
A type of malocclusion in which there is a gap between the anterior teeth (incisors)
Absence or underdevelopment of the pubic bone
Abnormal ossification of the pubic bone
Abnormal ossification (bone tissue formation) affecting the pubic bone, also known as the pubis

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la osificación ósea de la pelvis

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the bony pelvis
#Abnormal ossification involving the bones of the pelvis
Abnormal ossification involving the femoral head and neck

A congenital failure of muscular development of part or all of one or both hemidiaphragms, resulting in superior displacement of abdominal viscera and altered lung development
Congenital absence of the left half of the diaphragm
A decrease in the strength of the diaphragm

The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx

trans-unit.target: Contractura de la articulación interfalángica proximal del quinto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) flexion deformity of the little finger. That is, the PIP joint of a little finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement
Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 5th finger

A pseudoepiphysis is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis. The normal metacarpal epiphyses are located at the distal ends of the metacarpal bones. Accessory epiphyses (which are also known as pseudoepiphyses) can also occasionally be observed at the proximal ends of the metacarpals, usually involving the 2nd metacarpal bone

trans-unit.source: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. That is, the PIP joint of a fourth finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement

trans-unit.target: Sinfalangismo distal/medio del cuarto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Fusion of the terminal/distal and middle phalanges of the 4th finger
#Symphalangism of the distal and middle phalanges of the 4th finger
Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Falange distal del cuarto dedo de la mano en forma triangular

trans-unit.source: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the 4th (ring) finger. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx
Patchy sclerosis of the middle phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Esclerosis irregular de la falange media del cuarto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Uneven (irregular) increase in bone density of the middle phalanx of the fourth finger
Symphalangism of middle phalanx of 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Sinfalangismo de la falange media del cuarto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Fusion of the middle phalanx of the 4th finger with another bone
Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Falange media del cuarto dedo de la mano en forma triangular

trans-unit.source: Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 4th (ring) finger. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx
Broad proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Falange proximal ancha del cuarto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Increased width of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
Bullet-shaped proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Falange proximal del cuarto dedo del pie en forma de bala

trans-unit.source: Bullet-shaped phalanx refers to a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally . Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction. This term is used if the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger is affected
Osteolytic defects of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Defectos osteolíticos de la falange proximal del cuarto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
Patchy sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Esclerosis irregular de la falange proximal del cuarto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Uneven (irregular) increase in bone density of the proximal phalanx of the fourth finger
Symphalangism affecting the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Sinfalangismo afectando la falange proximal del cuarto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger with another bone
Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
trans-unit.target: Falange proximal en forma triangular del cuarto dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the 4th (ring) finger. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx
Abnormality of the phalanges of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de las falanges del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the phalanges of the 3rd (middle) finger
#Abnormality of 3rd finger phalanges #Abnormality of middle finger phalanges

trans-unit.target: Desviación del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Displacement of the 3rd finger from its normal position

trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia del tercer dedo de la mano
Contractura de la articulación del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Chronic loss of joint motion in the 3rd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 3rd finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected
Abnormality of the epiphyses of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the proximal, middle, and distal phalanges of the 3rd finger
Absent epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Epífisis ausentes de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Absence of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
Bracket epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de corchete de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: The epiphysis is normally located on the proximal surface of the phalanges. Bracket epiphysis refers to an abnormality in which the epiphysis surrounds the phalanx, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of the phalanx to the distal side
Cone-shaped epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de cono de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx
Enlarged epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Epífisis agrandada de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger with respect to age-dependent norms
Fragmentation of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Fragmentación de la epífisis de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Fragmented appearance of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
Irregular epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Epífisis irregular de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Irregular radiographic opacity of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
Ivory epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Epífisis de marfil de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays
Pseudoepiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Pseudoepífisis de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: A pseudoepiphysis is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis
Small epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Epífisis pequeña de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Abnormally small size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger with respect to age-dependent norms
Stippling of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Punteado de la epífisis de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
Triangular epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
trans-unit.target: Epífisis triangular de la falange media del tercer dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat

trans-unit.target: Desviación radial del dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Bending or curvature of a finger toward the radial side (i.e., towards the thumb). The deviation is at the metacarpal-phalangeal joint, and this finding is distinct from clinodactyly
