trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de corchete del segundo dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Bracket epiphysis refers to an abnormality in which the epiphysis surrounds a phalangeal bone, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of a phalanx to the distal side

trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de cono del segundo dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the 2nd finger of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of a phalanx

trans-unit.target: Epífisis agrandadas del segundo dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the 2nd finger with respect to age-dependent norms

trans-unit.target: Epífisis de marfil del segundo dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the 2nd finger, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays

trans-unit.target: Pseudoepífisis del segundo dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: A pseudoepiphysis is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis

A vestibular Schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma, acoustic neurinoma, or acoustic neurilemoma) is a benign, usually slow-growing tumor that develops from the VIIIth cranial nerve supplying the inner ear
#Acoustic Neuroma #Vestibular neurilemmoma #Vestibular neurinoma #Vestibular neurolemmoma #Vestibular Schwann cell tumor

trans-unit.target: Anomalía del viii par craneal o nervio vestíbulococlear

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the vestibulocochlear nerve, the eighth cranial nerve, which is involved in transmitting sound and equilibrium information from the inner ear to the brain
#Abnormality of the eighth cranial nerve #Abnormality of the VIIIth cranial nerve
Astrocytoma is a neoplasm of the central nervous system derived from astrocytes. Astrocytes are a type of glial cell, and thus astrocytoma is a subtype of glioma
The presence of a peripheral schwannoma
A hamartoma (a benign, focal malformation consisting of a disorganized mixture of cells and tissues) of the retina
Neurofibromas present in a smaller number than usually seen in neurofibromatosis type 1

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de las epífisis del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the proximal, and distal phalanges of the thumb and/or the 1st metacarpal
#Abnormality of the epiphyses of the thumb #Abnormality of thumb epiphyses
Chronic loss of joint motion in the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected
#Contracture of thumb #Flexion deformities of thumbs #Joint contractures of the thumb

#Absent or hypoplastic thumbs #Absent/hypoplastic thumb #Absent/hypoplastic thumbs #Aplasia/hypoplasia of thumbs #Aplastic/hypoplastic thumbs #Hypoplastic to aplastic thumbs #Hypoplastic/absent thumb #Thumb aplasia/hypoplasia

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la falange del pulgar

trans-unit.source: A structural anomaly of one or more phalanges of the thumb
Displacement of the thumb from its normal position
Complete duplication of distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Duplicación completa de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side
#Double thumb distal phalanges #Duplicated terminal phalanx of thumb #Duplication of distal thumb phalanx #Duplication of terminal thumb phalanx
Complete duplication of proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Duplicación completa de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Partail or complete duplication of the first metacarpal bone
Bifid distal phalanx of the thumb

Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones
#Bifid distal phalanx of thumb #Bifid terminal phalanges of thumbs #Incipient distal thumb phalanx duplication #Notched terminal thumb phalanx
Duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Duplicación de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Complete or partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side
#Partial/complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb
Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Duplicación de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Complete or partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
#Partial/complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
Bifid proximal phalanx of the thumb

This term applies if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is partially duplicated. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Complete duplication of the first metacarpal
Complete duplication of the first metacarpal bone
Partial duplication of the first metacarpal bone
Abnormality of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Any anomaly of the distal phalanx of thumb
Abnormality of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Insertion of thumb at a more distal location than normal

Contractures of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Contracturas de la articulación carpometacarpiana del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Chronic loss of joint motion of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is formed by the first metacarpal and the trapezial bone and is also called Articulatio carpometacarpalis pollicis, carpometacarpal articulation of thumb, carpometacarpal joint of thumb or first carpometacarpal articulation. Seldom referred to as thumb saddle joint
Contractures of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Contracturas de la articulación metacarpofalángica del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio metacarpophalangealis pollicis

trans-unit.target: Contracturas de la articulación interfalángica del dedo pulgar

trans-unit.source: Chronic loss of joint motion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio interphalangealis pollicis

trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: This term applies if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is either small/hypoplastic or absent. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

Abnormality of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb. This epiphysis is located on the proximal end of the phalanx
Abnormality of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: This term applies if the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, which is located at the proximal end of the phalanx, does not appear in concordance with gender and age dependant norms as seen on x-rays. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Absent epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis ausentes de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Absence of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Bracket epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de corchete de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: The epiphysis is normally located on the proximal surface of the phalanges. Bracket epiphysis refers to an abnormality in which the epiphysis surrounds the phalanx, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of the phalanx to the distal side
Cone-shaped epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de cono de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the thumb of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Enlarged epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis agrandada de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Fragmentation of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Fragmentación de la epífisis de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb having multiple bony fragments
Irregular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis irregular de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Irregular radiographic opacity of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Ivory epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis de marfil de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays
Pseudoepiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Pseudoepífisis de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
Small epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis pequeña de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Abnormally small size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms
Stippling of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Punteado de la epífisis de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Triangular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis triangular de la falange proximal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Absent epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis ausentes de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Absence of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the thumb
Bracket epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de corchete de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: The epiphysis is normally located on the proximal surface of the phalanges. Bracket epiphysis refers to an abnormality in which the epiphysis surrounds the phalanx, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of the phalanx to the distal side
Cone-shaped epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de cono de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx
Enlarged epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis agrandada de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms
Fragmentation of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb

Irregular epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb

Ivory epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb

trans-unit.source: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays
Pseudoepiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Pseudoepífisis de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of the distal phalanx of the thumb
Small epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis pequeña de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Abnormally small size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms
Stippling of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Punteado de la epífisis de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
Triangular epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
trans-unit.target: Epífisis triangular de la falange distal del pulgar

trans-unit.source: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat
Absence of one or more epiphyses of the thumb

trans-unit.target: Epífisis en froma de corchetes del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Bracket epiphysis refers to an abnormality in which the epiphysis surrounds a phalangeal bone, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of a phalanx to the distal side

trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de cono del pulgar

trans-unit.source: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the thumb, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of a phalanx
#Cone-shaped epiphyses of the thumb #Cone-shaped thumb epiphyses
Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms

trans-unit.target: Fragmentación de la epífisis del pulgar

trans-unit.source: Epiphysis of the thumb having multiple bony fragments
#Fragmentation of the epiphyses of the thumb
Uneven radiographic opacity of the one or more epiphyses of the thumb
Sclerosis of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays
A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of one or more phalanges of the thumb
Abnormally small size of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb
#Stippling of the epiphyses of the thumb
Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers
trans-unit.target: Contractura de las articulaciones interfalángicas distales de los dedos de la mano

trans-unit.source: Chronic loss of joint motion in one or more distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers
Osteolytic defects of the hand bones
trans-unit.target: Defectos osteolíticos de los huesos de la mano

trans-unit.source: Synostosis involving bones of the fingers
trans-unit.target: Sinostosis comprometiendo huesos de los dedos de la manos

trans-unit.source: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term "symphalangism of the hand" may be translated as fusions of bones of varying digree, that involve at least one phalangeal bone of the hand. If bony fusions are revered to as "Symphalangism" the fusion occurs in a proximo-distal axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a radio-ulnar axis are refered to as "bony" Syndactyly

Fusion involving two or more metacarpal bones (A synostosis of the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb can also be observed, note that the first metacarpal bone corresponds to a proximal phalanx)
#Synostosis involving metacarpal bones #Synostosis involving the metacarpal bones
Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the carpus (scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate, pisiform)
#Carpal bone fusion #Carpal fusion #Fused carpal bones #Synostosis involving the carpal bones

Fusion of the 1st metacarpal with another bone. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2 to 5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
#First metacarpophalangeal joint synostosis #Symphalangism affecting the 1st metacarpal
Chronic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis is defined as the finding, in at least two serial CSF examinations, of more than 5 cells per cubic millimeter

trans-unit.target: Aumento de interferón alfa en líquido cefaloraquídeo

trans-unit.source: Increased concentration of interferon alpha in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
A benign vascular tumor of the retina without any neoplastic characteristics
A cystadenoma, an epithelial tumor, that originates within the head of the epididymis

Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis or nodular heterotopia of grey matter

Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients

A demarcated, largely intraventricular tumor in the region of the foramen of Monro composed of spindle to large plump or ganglion-like cells with eosinophilic to amphophilic cytoplasm and somewhat pleomorphic nuclei with occasional prominent nucleoli. These tumors are almost always associated with tuberous sclerosis

Hypomelanotic macules ("ash leaf spots") are white or lighter patches of skin that may appear anywhere on the body and are caused by a lack of melanin. White ash leaf-shaped macules are considered to be characteristic of tuberous sclerosis
The presence of a sebaceous adenoma with origin in the sebum secreting cells of the skin

A plaque representing a connective-tissue nevus. Connective tissue naevi are uncommon skin lesions that occur when the deeper layers of the skin do not develop correctly or the components of these layers occur in the wrong proportion. Shagreen patches are oval-shaped and nevoid, skin-colored or occasionally pigmented, smooth or crinkled, The word shagreen refers to a type of roughened untanned leather

trans-unit.target: Fositas o muescas (pits) del esmalte dental

trans-unit.source: The presence of small depressions in the dental enamel
A lesion located beneath a fingernail or toenail
The presence of fibromata beneath finger or toenails
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary bladder
The presence of a neoplasm of the kidney
#Kidney cancer #Neoplasia of the kidneys #Renal neoplasia #Renal tumors
Areas of the retina lacking pigmentation. Punched out areas of chorioretinal hypopigmentation less than 1 disc diameter in size and tending to be located in the midperiphery of the retina
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in striated muscle, either skeletal muscle or cardiac muscle
A benign tumor of cardiac striated muscle
A benign tumor of striated muscle
The presence of a hamartoma of the cerebrum
A neurofibroma in which Schwann cells proliferate inside the nerve sheath, producing an irregularly thickened, distorted, tortuous structure
The presence of a glioma, which is a neoplasm of the central nervous system originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes)
A glioma originating in the optic nerve or optic chiasm

Pseudarthrosis, or "false joint" of the tibia is the result of a developmental failure in the tibia progressing to spontaneous fracture and subsequent fibrous nonunion. The fracture is rarely present at birth but commonly develops during the first 18 months of life
The presence of pigmented, oval and dome-shaped raised hamartomatous nevi of the iris.
Nephrosclerosis refers to thickening or scarring ("sclerosis") resulting from damage to the renal arterioles, also referred to as arteriosclerosis of the kidney arteries
Shoulder joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in shoulders when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity
Abnormality of the spinal dura mater
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la duramadre de la médula espinal

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the spinal dura mater, which is the outermost of the three layers of the meninges surrounding the spinal cord
Presence of arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal extradurally in the epidural space
#Epidural arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal
Abnormally increased thickness of the nasal septum
Abnormally increased hair growth in the lumbosacral region
Increased volume of the earlobe, that is, abnormally prominent ear lobules
#Fleshy earlobe #Fleshy earlobes #Prominent ear lobes #prominent ear lobules
Aplasia of the pectoralis major muscle
Absence of the pectoralis major muscle

trans-unit.target: Hendidura de la base del cráneo

trans-unit.source: A bony defect in the skull base
Complete or nearly complete soft tissue fusion of the alveolar ridges
Partial fusion of the upper and lower eyelid margins by single or multiple bands of tissue
A pterygium (or pterygia) occuring in the popliteal region (the back of the knee)
A pterygium (or pterygia) in the intercrural (groin) region
Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails
trans-unit.target: Pliegue cutáneo piramidal que se extiende desde la base hasta la parte superior de las uñas

trans-unit.source: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails is a rare and distinctive anomaly seen in popliteal pterygia syndrome
Pterygium affecting the elbow. This is a cutaneous web that can lead to severe flexion contracture of the elbow joint. Antecubital pterygium can be unilateral, bilateral, symmetric, or asysmmetric

trans-unit.target: Fisura anterior de los cuerpos vertebrales

trans-unit.source: Anterior schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies
Excessive wrinkling of the skin of the face
Chronic pain in the limbs with no clear focal etiology
Columella extending inferior to the level of the nasal base, when viewed from the side
#Columella extends below the ala nasi #Columella, low #Columella, low hanging #Extension of the columella below the ala nasi #Low-hanging columella
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Small or missing phalangeal bones of the fingers of the hand
#Aplastic/hypoplastic phalanges #Aplastic/hypoplastic phalanges of the hand #Hypoplastic/absent phalanges
Increased width of the phalanges of the hand

trans-unit.target: Falanges en forma de bala de la mano

trans-unit.source: The presence of short and wide phalanges which taper distally ("bullet shaped")
#Bullet-shaped phalanges of the hands #Conical bullet-shaped distal ends of phalanges
Osteolytic defects of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Defectos osteolíticos de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of the phalanges of the hand

trans-unit.target: Esclerosis irregular de la falange del dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: Uneven (irregular) increase in bone density of one or more of the phalanges of the hand
#Patchy sclerosis of the phalanges of the hand #Phalangeal sclerosis
Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Sinfalangismo que afecta a las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Fusion of two or more phalangeal bones of the hand
Triangular shaped phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Falanges de la mano en forma triangular

trans-unit.source: Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands
The absence of all phalanges of all the digits of a limb and the associated soft tissues
Absent thumb, i.e., the absence of both phalanges of a thumb and the associated soft tissues
Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the thumb
#Hypoplastic thumb #Hypoplastic thumbs #Hypoplastic/small thumb #Short thumbs #Small thumbs #Thumb brachydactyly #Thumb hypoplasia
Syndactyly with fusion of toes three and four

Horn-like malformations of the iliac crests with symmetrical bilateral central posterior iliac processes. A characteristic finding in the Nail-Patella syndrome. Iliac horns are visible on X-ray and may be palpable, but are asymptomatic
A zone of darker pigmentation around the central part of the iris with a roughly cloverleaf or flower shape
Absence or underdevelopment of the biceps muscle
Absence or underdevelopment of the triceps muscle
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the musculature of the thigh
trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de la musculatura del muslo

trans-unit.source: Absence or underdevelopment involving the musculature of the thigh
Absence or underdevelopment of the quadriceps muscle
The presence of an abscess located around the anus
A hemisacral defect involving the sacral vertebrae S2 to S5
Presence of a bifid sacral bone
Presence of a teratoma anterior to the sacrum
Congenital developmental defect arising from the primitive branchial apparatus
A congenital fistula in the neck resulting from incomplete closure of a branchial cleft

A branchial cyst is a remnant of embryonic development resulting from a failure of obliteration of a branchial cleft and consists of a subcutaneous cystic mass. Cysts are located anterior or posterior to the ear or in the submandibular region

Cholesteatoma is a benign but potentially destructive growth consisting of keratinizing epithelium located in the middle ear and/or mastoid process. In cholesteatoma, a skin cyst grows into the middle ear and mastoid. The cyst is not cancerous but can erode tissue and cause destruction of the ear
A goiter that is not associated with functional thyroid abnormalities
The presence of two or more accessory spleens

Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes
Aplasia of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Aplasia de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Absence of one or more of the phalanges of the hand

trans-unit.target: Acortamiento de las falanges de los dedos

trans-unit.source: Short (hypoplastic) phalanx of finger, affecting one or more phalanges
#Hypoplastic phalanges #Hypoplastic phalanges of hands #Hypoplastic/small phalanges of the hand #Phalangeal hypoplasia #Rudimentary phalanges #Short fingers #Short phalanges #Shortened phalanges
The presence of a reduced number of teeth as in Hypodontia or as in Anodontia

trans-unit.target: Falla cardíaca congestiva de bajo gasto

trans-unit.source: A form of heart failure characterized by reduced cardiac output. This may be seen in patients with heart failure owing to ischemic heart disease, hypertension, cardiomyopathy, and other causes
A form of diabetes insipidus caused by failure of the kidneys to respond to vasopressin (AVP)
Anomaly of the upper limb diaphyses
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de las diáfisis de los miembros superiores

trans-unit.source: A structural abnormality of a diaphysis of the arm

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de metáfisis del miembro superior

trans-unit.source: An anomaly of one or more metaphyses of the arms

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de las articulaciones de los miembros superiores

trans-unit.source: #Abnormality of the joints of the upper limbs
An anomaly of the joint that connects the upper and the lower arm
Amelia of one or both upper limbs

Missing or malformed long bones of the upper limbs with the distal parts (the hands) connected to the variably shortened or even absent upper extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the whole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia)
Peromelia affecting only the upper limbs. That is, the distal parts of the arm are missing leading to stump formation
Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the extremities
#Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving bones of the extremities #Short or absent limbs #Shortened limbs
Leg shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the lower extremity
#Hypoplasia involving bones of the lower limbs #Hypoplasia of the lower limbs
Aplasia involving bones of the lower limbs
trans-unit.target: Aplasia de los huesos de los miembros inferiores

trans-unit.source: Amelia of one or both legs
Phocomelia affecting only the lower limbs
Peromelia affecting only the lower limbs. That is, the distal parts of the leg are missing leading to stump formation
Forearm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the forearm
#Hypoplasia involving forearm bones #Short forearm bones #Short forearms #Shortened forearm

trans-unit.target: Aplasia de los huesos del antebrazo

trans-unit.source: Aplasia involving bones of the upper limbs
trans-unit.target: Aplasia de los huesos de las extremidades superiores

trans-unit.source: Arm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the upper extremity
#Hypoplasia involving bones of the upper limbs #Short arms #Shortening of the arms
Aplasia involving bones of the extremities
trans-unit.target: Aplasia de los huesos de las extremidades

trans-unit.source: Limb shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the extremities
#Hypoplasia involving bones of the extremities #limb shortening #Short limb #Short limbs
Congenital absence (aplasia) of one or more limbs
The distal parts of the limbs are missing leading to a stump formation

Missing or malformed long bones of the extremities with the distal parts (such as hands and/or feet) connected to the variably shortened or even absent extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the hole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia)

Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course
A focal lesion of a single peripheral nerve. Damage to a sensory nerve is accompanied by sensory impairment of all modalities in the affected anatomic distribution

trans-unit.source: Any anomaly of distal phalanx of finger

An abnormal reduction of the number and complexity of the pattern of gyrations of the cerebral cortex

#Brachytelophalangy #Distal phalangeal hypoplasia #Hypoplasia of the distal phalanges #Hypoplasia of the distal phalanges of the hand #Hypoplasic terminal phalanges #Hypoplastic distal phalanges #Hypoplastic terminal phalanges #Short distal phalanges #Terminal phalangeal hypoplasia of hand
Duplication of the distal phalanx of hand
trans-unit.target: Duplicación de la falange distal de la mano

trans-unit.source: This term applies if one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated
#Bifid terminal phalanges #Partial/complete duplication of the distal phalanges of the hand
A reduction in diameter of the distal phalanx of finger towards the distal end
#Tapered distal phalanges #Tapered distal phalanges of the hand

Trichorrhexis nodosa is the formation of nodes along the hair shaft through which breakage readily occurs. It is thus a focal defect in the hair fiber that is characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. The result is defective, abnormally fragile hair

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de la pigmentación del pelo

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the growth of secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty. In males, secondary sexual hair usually comprises body hair, including underarm, abdominal, chest, and pubic hair. In females, secondary sexual hair usually comprises a lesser degree of body hair, most prominently underarm and pubic hair
Abnormally increased hair growth with a localized distribution

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the hairline and the glabella
Flatness of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones

#Depressed supraorbital ridge #Flat supraorbital ridge #Hypoplasia of the supraorbital ridges #Hypoplastic supraorbital ridges #Shallow orbital ridges #Shallow supraorbital ridge #Underdeveloped brows
Complete absence of any auricular structures
#Absent ear #Absent ears #Congenital absence of external ear
The presence of telangiectasia of the ear
Increased thickness of the external ear
Abnormality of the crus of the helix
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la cruz del hélix

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the crus of the helix (FMA:61024), which is the horizontal piece of cartilage located outside the ear canal that divides the upper and lower parts of the ear
#Abnormality of the crus of the ear
An abnormality of the antitragus, which is a small tubercle opposite to the tragus of the ear. The antitragus and the tragus are separated by the intertragic notch

An abnormal horizontal axis orientation of the crus of the helix (FMA:61024). That is, the main axis of the crus of the helix is perpendicular to the medial longitudinal axis of the ear, instead of sloping inferoposteriorly
#Helix, crus, horizontal #Horizontal orientation of the crus of helix #Horizontal orientation of the ear crus

trans-unit.target: Desarrollo insuficiente del crus del hélix

trans-unit.source: Developmental hypoplasia of the crus of the helix (FMA:61024). That is, flatter and/or shorter crus helix than average
#Hypoplasia of the crus of the ear #Underdeveloped crus of the ear
The presence of an abnormally prominent of the crus of the helix (FMA:61024). That is, development of the crus helix to the same degree as an average antihelix stem or helix
#Abnormal prominence of the crus of the ear #Helix, crus, prominent #Hyperplastic helix crus #Hypertrophic helix crus
A unilateral absence of sensory perception of sound
Distortion of the course of the normal folds of the ear and the appearance of supernumerary crura and folds
A notched form of the helix of the ear. That is, a defect in the continuity of the helix, which may occur at any point along its length
Presence of nodules in the conjunctiva of the eye
Decreased thickness of thehelix of the ear

trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de los lóbulos de las orejas

trans-unit.source: Absence or underdevelopment of the ear lobes
Attachment of the lobe to the side of the face at the lowest point of the lobe without curving upward

trans-unit.target: Pliegues anteriores en el lóbulo de la oreja

trans-unit.source: Sharply demarcated, typically linear and approximately horizontal, indentations in the outer surface of the ear lobe
An abnormal orientation of the earlobes such that they point out- and upward. That is, the lateral surface of ear lobe faces superiorly
#Fleshy upturned lobules #Lobe, uplifted #Uplifted earlobes #Upturned earlobe #Upturned earlobes
Aplasia of the middle ear ossicles
trans-unit.target: Aplasia de los huesecillos del oído medio

trans-unit.source: Absence of the middle ear ossicles, malleus, incus, and stapes
Abnormality of the temporal bone of the skull, which is situated at the sides and base of the skull roughly underlying the region of the face known as the temple
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the tragus
Cyclopia is a congenital abnormality in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose
The presence of a size difference between the left and right cornea
Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, may represent a benign physiologic variant or a manifestation of disease
The presence of remnants of a fetal membrane that persist as strands of tissue crossing the pupil
A malposition of the pupil owing to a developmental defect of the iris
A tumor of the eye originating from cells of the retina

A macular lesion on the side of the face, involving the conjunctiva and eyelids, as well as the adjacent facial skin, sclera, oculomotor muscles, and perisoteum. Histological features vary from those of a Mongoloian spot to those of a blue nevus

Duane anomaly is a congenital eye movement impairment with limitation of the ability to adduct or abduct the eye. When affected eyes are adducted (moved inwards towards the nose), the eyeball retracts and the palpebral fissure narrows
#Globe retraction and deviation on adduction #Limited eye motility from Duane anomaly #Limited eye movement from Duane anomaly

Persistence of the hyaloid artery, which is the embryonic artery that runs from the optic disk to the posterior lens capsule may persist; the site of attachment may form an opacity. The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, and usually regresses completely before birth
Underdevelopment or absence of the nose or parts thereof
Abnormally increased lacrimation, that is, excessive tearing (watering eye)
Complete absence of all nasal structures
Increase in bulk of the ala nasi
#Ala nasi, thick #Thickening of the alae nasi
Asymmetry or size difference between the left and right nostril
The presence of only a single nostril
Slender, slit-like aperture of the nostril
The presence of more than two nostrils
Absence or underdevelopment of the nasal septum
Lack or loss of the soft tissues between the zygomata and mandible
Lack of symmetry between the left and right mandible
#Asymmetry of lower jaw #Deviation of lower jaw #Deviation of mandible #Lower jaw shifted to one side
The presence of an asymmetric mouth

Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
#Complete/partial duplication of phalanges of the thumb #Duplicated thumb #Duplicated thumbs #Duplication of phalanx of thumb

A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also refered to as Hyperphalangism

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis del primer metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits). The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end (as seen in the proximal phalanges of the other digits), whereas the epiphyses of the other metacarpal bones are located at the distal end. This term applies if the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal is in any way abnormal, referring to age and gender depending norms, as seen on x-rays

trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de corchete del primer metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: An epiphysis that curves around from its transverse orientation to a longitudinal one from proximal to distal along one side of the phalanx, thus resembling the letter 'C' and forming a bracket around the diaphysis. This results in a so called delta phalanx characterized by a triangular or trapezoidal shaped bone with a C-shaped epiphyseal plate

trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de cono del primer metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance
Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the 1st metacarpal with respect to age-dependent norms
Fragmentation of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
trans-unit.target: Fragmentación de la epífisis del primer metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: Epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal having multiple bony fragments

trans-unit.target: Epífisis de marfil del primer metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: The epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs
The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone although an accessory epiphysis may be located at the distal end of the metacarpal
Abnormally small size of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal with respect to age-dependent norms
Epiphyseal stippling of the first metacarpal
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphyses of the first metacarpal bone
#Stippling of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal

trans-unit.target: Contractura en flexión del dedo gordo del pie

trans-unit.source: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the first (big) toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively
Contracture of the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux
trans-unit.target: Contractura de la articulación tarsometatarsiana del dedo gordo del pie

trans-unit.source: Chronic loss of joint motion in the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The tarsometatarsal joints of the feet are also called Lisfranc's joints
Contracture of the interphalangeal joint of the hallux
trans-unit.target: Contractura de la articulación interfalángica del dedo gordo del pie

trans-unit.source: The interphalangeal joint of the big toe cannot be straightened actively or passively
Contractures of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the hallux
trans-unit.target: Contracturas de la articulación metatarsofalángica del dedo gordo del pie

trans-unit.source: The joint between the first metatarsal and the proximal phalanx of the first (big) toe cannot be straightened actively or passively

A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the bones of the foot (as well as muscle and soft tissue). In contrast if only the muscle and soft tissue are affected the term positional foot deformity applies
Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 2nd metacarpal
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis del segundo metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the second metacarpal bone

The normal epiphysis of the second metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present
Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 3rd metacarpal
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis del tercer metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the third metacarpal bone

The normal epiphysis of the third metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present
Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 4th metacarpal
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis del cuarto metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the 4th metacarpal bone

The normal epiphysis of the fourth metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present
Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 5th metacarpal
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis del quinto metacarpiano

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the fifth metacarpal bone

The normal epiphysis of the fifth metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present
Absent epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Epífisis ausentes de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Absence of one or more epiphyses of the phalanges fingers
Bracket epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de corchete de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Bracket epiphysis refers to an abnormality in which the epiphysis surrounds a phalangeal bone, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of a phalanx to the distal side
Cone-shaped epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Epífisis en forma de cono de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the fingers of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of a phalanx

#Cone-shaped epiphyses (hand) #Cone-shaped epiphyses of phalanges #Cone-shaped epiphyses of the fingers #Cone-shaped phalangeal epiphyses #Coned epiphyses #Coned epiphyses of hands #Conical phalangeal epiphyses #Phalangeal cone-shaped epiphyses
Enlarged epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Epífisis agrandada de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers with respect to age-dependent norms
#Enlarged epiphyses of the fingers #Enlarged phalangeal epiphyses
Fragmentation of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Fragmentación de las epífisis de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Fragmented appearance of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers
#Fragmentation of the epiphyses of the fingers
Irregular epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Epífisis irregulares de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Irregular radiographic opacity of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers
Ivory epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Epífisis de marfil de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays
#Ivory epiphyses of the fingers #Sclerotic ivory phalangeal epiphyses
Pseudoepiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Pseudoepífisis de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: A pseudoepiphysis is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis
Small epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
trans-unit.target: Epífisis pequeñas de las falanges de la mano

trans-unit.source: Stomatitis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes of any of the structures in the mouth
A gap in the lower lip

Height of the vermilion of the medial part of the lower lip more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the frontal view (subjective)
Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the mucosa of the mouth
Fibrous band between the mucosal surfaces of the upper and lower alveolar ridges
Any abnormality of the salivary glands, the exocrine glands that produce saliva

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de las glándulas salivares submandibulares

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the submandibular glands, which are the salivary glands that are located beneath the floor of the mouth, superior to the digastric muscles

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de las glándulas salivares sublinguales

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the sublingual glands, which are the salivary glands that are located beneath the floor of the mouth anterior to the submandibular glands
A gap (cleft) affecting one of the alveolar ridges

Distance between the labial point of the incisive papilla to the midline junction of the hard and soft palate more than 2 SD below the mean (objective) or apparently decreased length of the hard palate (subjective)
Increased size and/or number of soft tissue folds on the palatal side of the maxillary alveolar ridge
Underdevelopment or absence of the uvula
A fistula which connects the oral cavity and the pharyngeal area via the aspects of the soft palate
Absence or underdevelopment of the tongue
Short or anteriorly attached lingual frenulum, associated with limited mobility of the tongue
Tongue with a median apical indentation or fork
Glossy appearance of the entire tongue surface
A heterogeneous group of congenital spinal anomalies that result from defective closure of the neural tube early in fetal life
#Incomplete closure of the vertebral arch #Neural tube defect
A neoplasm affecting the spinal cord
#Spinal tumor #Spinal tumors #Tumor of the spinal cord

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de las meninges de la médula espinal

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the spinal meninges, the system of membranes (dura mater, the arachnoid mater, and the pia mater) which envelops the spinal cord
An outpouching of the spinal meninges
Reduced inferior to superior extent of the thorax
Stridor is a high pitched sound resulting from turbulent air flow in the upper airway
The congenital absence of the sternum
The sternal cleft is a rare congenital anomaly resulting from a fusion failure of the sternum
Accumulation of excessive amounts of lymphatic fluid (chyle) in the pleural cavity
Absence or underdevelopment of the breasts
The presence of hypertrophy of the breast
Absence or underdevelopment of the diaphragm
Ebstein's anomaly of the tricuspid valve
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de Ebstein de la válvula tricúspide

trans-unit.source: Ebstein's anomaly refers to an abnormally placed and deformed tricuspid valve characterized by apical displacement of the septal and posterior tricuspid valve leaflets, leading to atrialization of the right ventricle with a variable degree of malformation and displacement of the anterior leaflet

trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de la musculatura de la pared abdominal

trans-unit.source: Absence or underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature

Partial duplication of phalanx of the 2nd toe

Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 2nd toe

Aplasia of the phalanges of the 2nd toe

Acortamiento de la falange del segundo dedo del pie

Aplasia of the middle phalanx of the 2nd toe

Aplasia of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe
