trans-unit.source: Short proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe
trans-unit.target: Acortamiento de la falange proximal del segundo dedo del pie

trans-unit.source: Reduced length of the proximal phalanx of second toe as a result of developmental hypoplasia
#Hypoplastic/small proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe #Short proximal phalanx of the second toe
An abnormality of the interventricular septum

trans-unit.target: Apéndice accesorio con forma de dedo del pie

trans-unit.source: In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the fibular side of the foot, next top the little toe), preaxial (on the tibial side of the foot, next to the big toe) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between big and little toe), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes refered to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200)

trans-unit.target: Apéndice accesorio con forma de dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the ulnar side of the hand, next to the little finger), preaxial (on the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between thumb and little finger), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes refered to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200)
A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes
A bifid or bifurcated appearance of the femur as seen on x-rays, possible appearing as a more or less severe bowing of the upper leg. Might be associated with hip dysplasia on the affected side
The retrograde (backwards) flow of blood through the pulmonary valve into the right ventricle during diastole

An ostium primum atrial septal defect is located in the most anterior and inferior aspect of the atrial septum. The ostium primum refers to an anterior and inferior opening (ostium) within the septum primum, which divides the rudimentary atrium during fetal development. The ostium primum is normally sealed by fusion of the superior and inferior endocardial cushions around 5 weeks' gestation. Ostium primum defects result from a failure of the fusion of the embryologic endocardial cushion and septum primum
#Atrial septal defect, primum type #Ostium primum atrial septal defect #Primum atrioventricular canal defect #Septum primum defect
A narrowing of the orifice of the tricuspid valve of the heart
An abnormal connection between the epithelialised surface of the anal canal and the perianal skin
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the colon. That is, there is an abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the colon
#Atresia of the large intestine #Large intestinal atresia
An abnormal narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus
Absence or underdevelopment of the spleen
An abnormal (non-anatomic) location of the spleen
Pelvic asymmetry refers to asymmetric positioning of landmarks on the two sides of the pelvis and may have a structural or functional etiology
The presence of osteophytes (bone spurs), i.e., of bony projections originating from the acetabulum
An exageration of the normal arched form of the acetabular roof such that it takes on a steep appearance
Abnormality of the greater sacrosciatic notch
An abnormality of the sacrosciatic notch, i.e., the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium
Abnormally increased width of the greater sacrosciatic notch

Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In female pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is female (XX) and the gonads are ovaries, but the external genitalia are virilized
The presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues either in the same or in opposite gonads. Affected persons have ambiguous genitalia and may have 46,XX or 46,XY karyotypes or 46,XX/XY mosaicism
Abnormality of the female genital system
Abnormality of the male genital system
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the ovary
Aplasia, that is failure to develop, of the ovary

A developmental disorder characterized by the progressive loss of primordial germ cells in the developing ovaries of an embryo, leading to hypoplastic ovaries composed of wavy connective tissue with occasional clumps of granulosa cells, and frequently mesonephric or hilar cells
The onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls
Absence or underdevelopment of the testes
The presence of more than two testes
Increased urinary excretion of oligosaccharides (low molecular weight carbohydrate chains composed of at least three monosaccharide subunits), derived from a partial degradation of glycoproteins
Abnormality of the heme biosynthetic pathway
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la ruta de biosíntesis del hemo

trans-unit.source: An abnormality in the synthesis or catabolism of heme. Heme is composed of ferrous iron and protoporphyrin IX and is an essential molecule as the prosthetic group of hemeproteins such as hemoglobin, myoglobin, mitochondrial and microsomal cytochromes
Abnormally increased excretion of porphyrins in the urine
Buildups of minerals that form in the urinary bladder
Cloacal exstrophy is a severe anterior abdominal wall defect in which the two hemibladders are visible and are separated by a midline intestinal plate, an omphalocele, and an imperforate anus
Absence or underdevelopment of the urinary bladder
Persistence of the urachal canal resulting in a canal between the bladder and the umbilicus
The presence of an abnormal connection between the urethra and another organ or the skin
The presence of an abnormal membrane obstructing the urethra
Shortening of the arms predominantly affecting terminal parts of the arm in relation to the upper and middle limb segments
Amniotic constriction rings affecting the arms
Abnormal increase in size of the upper limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells)
The ability of the elbow joint to move beyond its normal range of motion
An abnormality of the hypothenar eminence, i.e., of the muscles on the ulnar side of the palm of the hand (i.e., on the side of the little finger)
Reduced muscle mass on the ulnar side of the palm, that is, reduction in size of the hypothenar eminence

trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de los pliegues palmares

trans-unit.source: Absence or underdevelopment of the palmar creases
The absence of the major creases of the palm (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, or thenar crease)
#Absence of the palmar creases #Aplasia of the palmar creases
An abnormality of the creases of the skin of palm of hand

trans-unit.target: Anillo de constricción en dígitos fetales

trans-unit.source: A narrow segment of significantly reduced circumference of a digit

Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual finger bones. Bony fusions are revered to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are refered to as "Symphalangism"
An abnormally increased length of the metacarpal bones
Shortening of the legs predominantly affecting terminal parts of the leg in relation to the upper and middle arm segments
Amniotic constriction rings affecting the legs
Abnormal increase in size of the lower limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells)
A developmental defect in which the legs are fused together
A developmental defect that occurs if the two halves of the patella fail to fuse in early childhood

The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar subluxation refers to an unstable kneecap that does not slide centrally within its groove, i.e., a partial dislocation of the patella
The ability of the knee joint to move beyond its normal range of motion

trans-unit.target: Limitación de la movilidad de la rodilla

trans-unit.source: An abnormal limitation of knee joint mobility
A bending or abnormal curvature of the fibula
Duplication of the fibula. This may occur as a part of diplopodia (accessory tarsal or metatarsal bone). Diplopodia with double fibula is an extremely rare condition

trans-unit.target: Aumento de la longitud de la tibia

trans-unit.source: An abnormal increase in the length of the tibia

trans-unit.target: Limitación de movimiento en los tobillos

trans-unit.source: An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the ankle joint
An abnormality of dermatoglyphs on the toes and soles, i.e., an abnormality of the patterns of ridges of the skin of sole of foot
A difference in size or shape between the left and right foot
A condition in which the anterior part of the foot rotates outward away from the midline of the body and the heel remains straight

trans-unit.target: Aplasia de los huesos del tarso
Hipermovilidad de las articulaciones de los pies

trans-unit.source: An ability of the toe joints to move beyond their normal range of motion
Digits that appear disproportionately long compared to the foot
Deposition of calcium salts in the pituitary gland

Hypersecretion of one or more pituitary hormones. This can occur in conditions in which deficiency in the target organ leads to decreased hormonal feedback, or as a primary condition most usually in connection with a pituitary adenoma
Absence or underdevelopment of the thymus

The presence of ectopic thymus tissue. Normally, cells of the ventral bud of the third pharyngeal pouch detach and migrate in the eighth gestational week caudally and medially towards the location of the mature thyroid. They migrate further retrosternally into the superior mediastinum. There are two main ways ectopic thymus tissue can develop. Either cells detach along the descensus path and proliferate, thereby forming accessory thymus tissue, or the entire gland fails to descend
An abnormality of the thyroid gland owing to the presence of a fibrous cyst resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct
An abnormal increase in quantity or strength of fetal movements
Gait apraxia affecting the ability to make walking movements with the legs

A learning disorder characterized primarily by difficulties in learning to read and spell. Dyslectic children also exhibit a tendency to read words from right to left and to confuse letters such as b and d whose orientation is important for their identification. Children with dyslexia appear to be impaired in phonemic skills (the ability to associate visual symbols with the sounds they represent)
An acquired type of sensory aphasia where damage to the brain leads to the loss of the ability to read

Inability to recognize objects not because of sensory deficit but because of the inability to combine components of sensory impressions into a complete pattern. Thus, agnosia is a neurological condition which results in an inability to know, to name, to identify, and to extract meaning from visual, auditory, or tactile impressions
An inability or difficulty differentiating among the fingers of either hand as well as the hands of others

A writing disability in the absence of motor or sensory deficits of the upper extremities, resulting in an impairment in the ability to write regardless of the ability to read and not due to intellectual impairment

Inability to recognize the form of objects by touch without visual input. That is, an impairment in the recognition of objects based only on based on the texture, size, weight and three-dimensional form of the object in the absence of any major somatosensory deficit
Inability to recognize faces of familair persons
The tendency to repeat vocalizations made by another person
Palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic (rhythmic involuntary jerky) movements of the soft palate

Spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor, infection, injury, or degenerative process of the spinal cord, and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions, usually at a rate of more than one per second. Myoclonus occurs synchronously in several muscles and can be increased in severity and frequency by fatigue or stress, but is usually unaffected by sensory stimuli. Spinal myoclonus ceases during sleep or anesthesia
The combination of pendular nystagmus, head nodding, and torticollis
A paroxysmal, transient loss of memory function with preservation of immediate recall and remote memory but with a severe impairment of memory for recent events and ability to retain new information

An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep. Apneas of at least 10 seconds are considered important, but persons with sleep apnea may have apneas of 20 seconds to up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep
Sleep apnea resulting from a transient abolition of the central drive to the ventilatory muscles
An abnormally increased width of the cranial sutures for age-related norms (generally resulting from delayed closure)
#open cranial sutures #open cranial sutures #Persistent wide fontanel #Widened cranial sutures
#hypoplasia of hypophseal fossa #hypoplasia of pituitary fossa #hypoplasia of sella turcica #small hypophyseal fossa #small pituitary fossa
The presence of an abnormally thin calvarium

trans-unit.target: Neumatización de los senos craneales acelerada

trans-unit.source: A degree of pneumatization that is increased compared to age-related norms

The presence of convoluted folds and furrows formed from thickened skin of the scalp, resembling cerebriform pattern. The scalp has convoluted and elevated folds, 1 to 2 cm in thickness. The convolutions generally cannot be flattened by traction
Nystagmus due to disturbance of the vestibular system; eye movements are rhythmic, with slow and fast components

Spontaneous, non-rhythmic, multi-directional, chaotic movements of the eyes, giving the appearance of agitation. There may be bursts of conjugate movement of the eyes in varying directions and of varying amplitude

Vertical nystagmus may present with either up-beating or down-beating eye movements or both. When present in the straight-ahead position of gaze it is referred to as upbeat nystagmus or downbeat nystagmus
Downbeat nystagmus is a type of fixation nystagmus with the fast phase beating in a downward direction. It generally increases when looking to the side and down and when lying prone

Fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers with little or no movement of the muscle as a whole. If a motor neuron or its axon is destroyed, the muscle fibers it innervates undergo denervation atrophy. This leads to hypersensitivity of individual muscle fibers to acetyl choline so that they may contract spontaneously. Isolated activity of individual muscle fibers is generally so fine it cannot be seen through the intact skin, although it can be recorded as a short-duration spike in the EMG

A type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching, which results from loss of all or practically all peripheral motor nerves that innervated the muscle. Muscle tone is reduced and the affected muscles undergo extreme atrophy within months of the loss of innervation
A localized myotonic contraction in a muscle in reaction to percussion (tapping with the examiner's finger, a rubber percussion hammer, or a similar object)
#Transient swelling of muscle induced by percussion
Weakness due to upper motor neuron dysfunction
trans-unit.target: Parálisis debida a lesiones de los tractos motores principales

trans-unit.source: Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Paralysis due to lesions of the principle motor tracts is related to a lesion in the corticospinal, corticobulbar or brainstem descending (subcorticospinal) neurons
#Paralysis due to lesions of the principle motor tracts
Severe or complete weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities
Weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities. Paraplegia refers to a severe or complete loss of strength, whereas paraparesis refers to a relatively mild loss of strength

An acute dystonic reaction with blepharospasm, periorbital twitches, and protracted fixed staring episodes. There may be a maximal upward deviation of the eyes in the sustained fashion. Oculogyric crisis can be triggered by a number of factors including neuroleptic medications

trans-unit.target: Sindactilia cutánea de dedo de la mano

trans-unit.source: A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal joint of the adjacent fingers

trans-unit.target: Superposición de los dedo de la manos

trans-unit.source: A finger resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the hand is at rest
An abnormality of the clivus, which is the inclined bony region of the posterior cranial fossa located between the sella turcica and the foramen magnum
An abnormal vertical orientation of the clivus (which normally forms a kind of slope from the sella turcica down to the region of the foramen magnum)
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the clavicles
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the ribs

Presence of one or more keloids. A keloid is a sharply elevated, irregularly shaped, progressively enlarging scar resulting from formation of excessive amounts of collagen in the dermis during connective tissue repair

A midline anterior-posterior cleft of the epiglottis that involves at least two-thirds of the epiglottic leaf. It is a useful feature for clinical diagnosis because it appears to be very rare in syndromes other than Pallister-Hall-Syndrome and is also rare as an isolated malformation
This term applies if the Epiglottis is absent or hypoplastic

A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that is native to the site of origin - eg, exostoses, nevi and soft tissue hamartomas. Although most hamartomas are benign, some histologic subtypes - eg, neuromuscular hamartoma, may proliferate aggressively such as mesenchymal cystic hamartoma, Sclerosing epithelial hamartoma, Sclerosing metanephric hamartoma

Y-shaped metatarsals are the result of a partial fusion of two metatarsal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metatarsals may be seen in combination with polydactyly
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) which can originate from any tissue of the eye
An abnormally low concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age
An abnormal elevation of phytanic acid
Abnormality of the epiphysis of the femoral head
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis de la cabeza femoral

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the femur
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the femoral head
A cystic lesion originating within the brain

Cone-shaped epiphyses (also known as coned epiphyses) are epiphyses that invaginate into cupped metaphyses. That is, the epiphysis has a cone-shaped distal extension resulting from increased growth of the central portion of the epiphysis relative to its periphery
An alteration of the normally smooth contour of the epiphysis leading to an irregular appearance
Sclerosis of the epiphyses, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays
Reduction in the size or volume of epiphyses

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at each end of a long bone, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone
Abnormality of the distal femoral epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis femoral distal

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the femur
Abnormality of the proximal tibial epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis tibial proximal

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the tibia
Abnormality of the distal tibial epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis tibial distal
Anomalía de las epífisis de peroné

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the proximal fibular epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis proximal del peroné

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the fibula
Abnormality of the distal fibular epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis distal del peroné

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the fibula
Abnormality of the proximal radial epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis radial proximal

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the radius
Abnormality of the distal radial epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis distal del radio

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the radius
Abnormality of the proximal humeral epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis proximal del húmero

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the humerus
Abnormality of the distal humeral epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis distal del húmero

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the humerus
Abnormality of the distal ulnar epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis distal del cúbito

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the ulna
Abnormality of the proximal ulnar epiphysis
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la epífisis cubital proximal

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the ulna
An abnormal predominance of type II muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy)

A benign uni- or multicystic, intraosseous tumor of odontogenic origin, with a characteristic lining of parakeratinized stratified squamous epithelium and potential for aggressive, infiltrative behaviour

A chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland. A chalazion or meibomian cyst appears as a painless tuberous swelling in the upper lid without loss of eyelashes

An acute purulent infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis at the base of the eyelashes, of the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or the meibomian sebacious glands often caused by staphylococcus infections. Hordeola can either occur as Hordeola externa affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or as Hordeola interna affecting the meibomian sebacious glands. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painful and can cause extreme local swelling

Hordeola externa are acute purulent infections affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling

Hordeola interna are acute purulent infections affecting the meibomian sebacious glands, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia (chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland), hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling

Cutaneous skin tags also known as acrochorda or fibroepithelial polyps are small benign tumours that may either form secondarily over time primarily in areas where the skin forms creases, such as the neck, armpit or groin or may also be present at birth, in which case they usually occur in the periauricular region
The presence of multiple pits (small, pinpoint-large indentations on the surface of the skin) located on the skin of sole of foot

Benign tumors that are composed of fibrous or connective tissue. They can grow in all organs, arising from mesenchyme tissue. The term "fibroblastic" or "fibromatous" is used to describe tumors of the fibrous connective tissue. When the term fibroma is used without modifier, it is usually considered benign, with the term fibrosarcoma reserved for malignant tumors
Angiofibroma consist of many often dilated vessels
The presence of a lung fibroma, a benign neoplasm that can present as a mass causing airway obstruction, cough, and hemoptysis, or present without symptoms as a solitary pulmonary nodule
The presence of a fibroma of the ovary
A benign biphasic tumor of the breast with epithelial and stromal components
Prominence of the malar process of the maxilla and infraorbital area appreciated in profile and from in front of the face
#Cheekbone prominence #Malar excess #Malar hyperplasia #Midface hyperplasia #Prominent malar region

trans-unit.target: Sindactilia cutánea de los dedos del pie

trans-unit.source: A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between adjacent foot digits that involves at least half of the proximodistal length of one of the two involved digits; or, a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits of the foot that does not meet the prior objective criteria
#Cutaneous syndactyly (feet) #soft tissue syndactyly of toes #Syndactyly, cutaneous (feet)
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skeleton
Absence or underdevelopment of the toenail
Absence or underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland, also known as the adenohypophysis
Absence of the pituitary gland resulting from a developmental defect
Underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland

Facial nerve palsy is a dysfunction of cranial nerve VII (the facial nerve) that results in inability to control facial muscles on the affected side with weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure. This can either be present in unilateral or bilateral form

#Bell's palsy #Cranial nerve VII palsy #Facial muscle weakness #Facial muscle weakness of muscles innervated by CN VII #Facial nerve palsy #Facial nerve paralysis #Facial palsy, unilateral or bilateral #Facial weakness #Seventh cranial nerve palsy #VII th cranial nerve palsy
Abnormality of the cortex of the humerus
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la corteza del húmero

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality affecting the cortex of the humerus

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de epífisis de los metatarsianos

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of a metatarsal bone epiphysis
#Abnormality of the epiphyses of the metatarsals
Abnormality of the epiphyses of the feet
trans-unit.target: Anomalía de las epífisis de los pies

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the epiphyses of the feet
Inability to detect any qualitative olfactory sensation
Inability to perceive certain odorants (implies that the sense of smell is maintained for other classes of odorants)
Reduced ability to detect any qualitative olfactory sensation
Reduced ability to perceive certain odorants (implies that the sense of smell is maintained for other classes of odorants)
The presence of a cleft in the cerebral cortex unilaterally or bilaterally, usually located in the frontal area
A form of amyloidosis that affects the conjunctiva
Elevated alkaline phosphatase of hepatic origin
trans-unit.target: Fosfatasa alcalina elevada de origen hepático

trans-unit.source: An abnormally increased level of liver isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood
Elevated alkaline phosphatase of bone origin
trans-unit.target: Fosfatasa alcalina elevada de origen óseo

trans-unit.source: An abnormally increased level of bone isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood
Abnormality of the nasal cavity (the cavity includes and starts at the nares and reaches all the way through to the and includes the choanae, the posterior nasal apertures)
Abnormality of the midnasal cavity which includes the cavity between the nares and the choanae

trans-unit.target: Atresia de la parte media de la nariz

trans-unit.source: Absence or abnormal closure of the midnasal cavity

trans-unit.target: Estenosis de la parte media de la nariz

trans-unit.source: Abnormal narrowing (stenosis) of the midnasal cavity, i.e., of the middle nasal meatus, which in neonates can cause respiratory distress
Aplasia of the distal phalanges of the toes
trans-unit.target: Aplasia de las falanges distales de los dedos de los pies

trans-unit.source: Absence of the distal phalanges of the toes
An abnormal lack of stability of the cervical spine
Any abnormal increase or reduction in skin elasticity
An abnormally increased ability of the skin to permit light to pass through (translucency) such that subcutaneous structures such as veins display an increased degree of visibility

An abnormal degree of flatness of the Ala of nose, which can be defined as a reduced nasal elevation index (lateral depth of the nose from the tip of the nose to the insertion of the nasal ala in the cheek x 100 divided by the side-to-side breadth of the nasal alae)

An abnormality of the premaxilla (the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla) causing it to appear relatively small in size compared to the other parts of the maxilla or other facial structures

#Hypoplasia of the intermaxillary bone #Hypoplasia of the primary palate bone #Premaxillary bone deficiency #Premaxillary retrusion #Premaxillary underdevelopment #Primary palate bone deficiency #Primary palate bone retrusion #Small premaxilla #Small primary palate bone #Underdevelopment of the premaxilla #Underdevelopment of the primary palate bone
An abnormality of the Meninges, including any abnormality of the Dura mater, the Arachnoid mater, and the Pia mater
An abnormality of the Dura mater
An abnormality of the Falx cerebri
A developmental defect characterized by aplasia of the Falx cerebri
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more epiphyses (FMA:24012)
#Epiphyseal punctate calcifications #Stippled epiphyses #Stippling of the epiphyses
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of an epiphysis
#Abnormality of the mineralisation or ossification of the epiphyses
Patchy reduction of bone mineral density
trans-unit.target: Disminución de la densidad mineral ósea en parches

trans-unit.source: Patchy (irregular) reduction in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays
Patchy changes of bone mineral density
trans-unit.target: Cambios irregulares de la densidad mineral ósea

trans-unit.source: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density. These changes can either be patchy reduction or increase of mineral density as seen on x-rays. Depending on the pathomechanism and the underlying disease, these changes can either appear solely as reduction or increase or as a combination of both (patches of bone showing an increased density while others are affected by reduction of mineral density)
Patchy variation in bone mineral density
trans-unit.target: Variación irregular en la densidad mineral ósea

trans-unit.source: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density with patches of bone showing an increased density side to side with patches that are affected by reduction of mineral density. This is sometimes referred to as a moth-eaten appearance on x-rays
#Patchy increased and decreased bone mineral density

trans-unit.target: Osificación anormal del hueso de la mano

Absence of the third cerebral ventricle
A developmental defect characterized by the absence of the Third ventricle
An abnormality of the Diencephalon, which together with the cerebrum (telencephalon) makes up the forebrain

A congenital defect characterized by absence of the Maxilla

An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase, intestinal type in the blood
An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase, placental type in the blood

A hand or foot with more than five digits that has a recognizable A/P axis of symmetry. The axis can lie within a normally formed or partially duplicated digit resembling a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe, or hallux. Alternatively, the axis can be in an interdigital space with a flanking pair of digits that resemble a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe or hallux. The most lateral digits on each side of the hand typically resemble fifth fingers/toes

trans-unit.target: Polidactilia en mano imagen en espejo

trans-unit.source: Mirror image duplication of digits affecting the hands only

trans-unit.target: Polidactilia de pie imagen en espejo

trans-unit.source: Mirror image duplication of digits affecting the feet

trans-unit.target: Sindactilia de dedos 2-5 de la mano

trans-unit.source: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two to five
A kind of congenital cataract that is characterized by a hollow sphere of punctate opacities involving the fetal nucleus and that usually occurs bilaterally
A Lamellar cataract with a pulverulent (punctate, "dust-like" opacities) appearance
A type of congenital cataract in which the opacity follows the anterior or posterior Y suture
A type of Congenital cataract in which the opacities occupy the subcapsular cortex at the anterior or posterior pole of the lens
A type of anterior polar cataract which projects as a conical opacity into the anterior chamber
A type of nuclear cataract involving congenital pulverulent disc-like opacity of the embryonal and fetal nucleus
#cataracta pulverulenta centralis #Central pulverulent cataract #Pulverulent nuclear cataract
A nuclear cataract with a triangular form
A Congenital cataract characterized by an opacity of all the fibers of a lens
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of immunoglobulins in blood
#abnormal immunoglobulin concentration #abnormal serum immunoglobulin concentration #Abnormal serum immunoglobulin levels #abnormal serum level of immunoglobulin #Immunoglobulin abnormality
An increased level of gamma globulin (immunoglobulin) in the blood

#Elevated immunoglobulin levels #Hypergammaglobulinaemia #Hypergammaglobulinemia #Hyperglobulinemia #Increased gamma globulin #Increased immunoglobulin level #Increased serum gamma globulin #Raised immunoglobulin levels

trans-unit.source: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one and two

Syndactyly with fusion of toes three to five

trans-unit.target: Sindactilia ósea de los dedos del pie

trans-unit.source: Webbing or fusion of the toes, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual bones of the toes. Bony fusions are revered to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a tibial-fibular axis. Fusions of bones of the toes in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "Symphalangism"

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de la textura del cabello

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the texture of the hair
#abnormality of hair consistency #abnormality of hair curl pattern #abnormality of hair volume
An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth
An abnormal hair whorl (that is, a patch of hair growing in the opposite direction of the rest of the hair)
An asymmetriy, i.e., difference in size, shape or position between the left and right ear

trans-unit.target: Lesiones quísticas de los pabellones auriculares

trans-unit.source: Advanced pneumatization of the mastoid process
trans-unit.target: Neumatización acelerada de la apófisis mastoides

trans-unit.source: An abnormally advanced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms
Abnormal prominence of the corneal nerve fibers
Rupture of the eyeball not due to trauma
A developmental defect characterized by absence of the retina
Cherry red spot of the macula
trans-unit.target: Mancha macular rojo cereza en la retina

trans-unit.source: Pallor of the perifoveal macula of the retina with appearance of a small circular reddish choroid shape as seen through the fovea centralis due to relative transparancy of the macula
This may present as a partial or complete duplication of the eyebrows
Extension of eyebrows towards upper eyelid
trans-unit.target: Extensión de las cejas hacia párpado superior

trans-unit.source: The eyebrows extend towards - or even all the way down to - the margin of the upper eyelid

trans-unit.target: Cambios nodulares que afectan a los párpados

trans-unit.source: Nodular changes affecting the eyelids may have many different causes such as cystic lesions (chalaziae, hordeolae), lipogranulomas, melanomas, infectious diseases (Molluscum contagiosum) and many more
Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the eyelid

Tumor-like growths that consist of replacement of the medullary bone with fibrous tissue, causing the expansion and weakening of the areas of bone involved. Especially when involving the skull or facial bones, the lesions can cause externally visible deformities. The skull is often, but not necessarily, affected, and any other bone or bones may be involved. Fibrous dysplasia can either effect isolated bones (Monostotic fibrous dysplasia) or also generalized all bones of the body (Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia)
Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in many bones throughout of the body. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is a cardinal feature of McCune-Albright syndrome
Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in only one bone

Osteopoikilosis is a benign, asymptomatic sclerotic dysplasia of the bones. It affects both male and female and may be seen at any age. Radiographically sclerotic circular or ovoid lesions are usually symmetrically distributed in a periarticular location. Lesions can increase or decrease in size and number in serial radiographs or even disappear and do not have increased bone radiotracer uptake

A lamellar pattern visible on radiographs and mainly localized at the metaphyses of the long tubular bones. Pathologic-anatomical studies revealed that these benign signs on x-rays are the result of a juvenile metaphyseal bone necrosis. Calcifications in the necrotic marrow lead to this lamellar or lattice-like appearance
An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin of the legs
An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin of the arms
Diminished length of a metatarsal bone, with resultant proximal displacement of the associated toe
#Hypoplasia of the metatarsal bones #Hypoplastic metatarsals #Short metatarsal bone #Short metatarsal bones #Short metatarsals #Shortened metatarsals
A developmental abnormality characterized by the absence (aplasia) of a metatarsal bone
Aplasia of the phalanges of the toes
trans-unit.target: Aplasia de las falanges de los dedos de los pies

trans-unit.source: Absence of a digit or of one or more phalanges of a toe
Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the toes
trans-unit.target: Hipoplasia de las falanges de los dedos de los pies

trans-unit.source: An abnormal distribution of eyebrow hair growth in the medial direction
Positioning of a lacrimal punctum other than at the medial margins of the eyelid

Blepharochalasis is characterized by recurrent, non-painful, nonerythematous episodes of eyelid edema. It has been divided into hypertrophic and atrophic forms. In the hypertrophic form recurrent edema results in orbital fat herniation through a weakened orbital septum. Most patients who have blepharochalasis present in an atrophic condition with atrophy of redundant eyelid skin and superior nasal fat pads
Loss of elasticity of the upper and lower eyelids causing the skin to sag and bulge
A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin
Midline deficiency of the mandible and some or all overlying tissues

trans-unit.target: Defecto de la línea media de la mandíbula

trans-unit.source: An anomaly of the temporomandibular joint
Asymmetry between the left and right sides of the maxilla
#Asymmetry of right and left side of the maxilla #Asymmetry of the upper jaw #Canted maxilla #Crooked maxilla #Tilted maxilla #Tilted upper jaw #unequal sides of maxilla
Absence or underdevelopment of the premaxilla
Absence of the Premaxilla, which is the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla

#Absence of the intermaxillary bone #Absence of the premaxilla #Absence of the primary palate bone #Aplasia of the intermaxillary bone #Aplasia of the primary palate bone #Missing premaxilla #Missing primary palate bone

An abnormality of the premaxilla [UBERON_0002244], the most anterior part of the maxilla that usually bears the central and lateral incisors and includes the anterior nasal spine and inferior aspect of the piriform rim. The premaxilla contains the bone and teeth of the primary palate
#Abnormality of the intermaxillary bone #Abnormality of the intermaxillary segment of the maxilla #Abnormality of the premaxillary bone #Abnormality of the primary palate bone
Prominent positioning of the premaxilla in relation to the rest of the maxilla, the facial skeleton, or mandible. Not necessarily caused by an increase in size (hypertrophy of) the premaxilla
#Anterior position of the premaxilla #Anterior position of the primary palate bone #Prominence of the intermaxillary bone #Prominence of the primary palate bone

trans-unit.target: Ausencia del dedo gordo del pie

trans-unit.source: Aplasia of a toe. That is, absence of all phalanges of a non-hallux digit of the foot and the associated soft tissues
#Absent toes #Aplasia of the toes #Aplasia of toe

A chordoma is a tumors that arises from embryonic remnants of the notochord along the length of the neuraxis. Chordomas generally occur in the sacrum, intracranially at the clivus, or along the spinal axis
Insertion of the posterior columella below the nasal base
Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand
Deposition of calcium salts in a tissue or location in which calcification does not normally occur
The presence of a cyst, fistula, or abscess in the sacrococcygeal region (gluteal crease) characteristically accompanied by hair and skin folds
A sinus in the coccygeal region (the region of the intergluteal cleft). A pilonidal sinus often contains hair and skin debris
A hair-containing cyst or sinus usually in the coccygeal region

A developmental defect characterized by abnormal connection of or more pulmonary veins to the superior or inferior vena cava, the right atrium, or the coronary sinus, resulting in a left-to-right shunt of oxygenated blood
A form of anomalous pulmonary venous return in which not all pulmonary veins drain abnormally. Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return frequently involves one or both of the veins from one lung
The presence of an additional membrane in the left or right cardiac atrium which results in the subdivision of the affected atrium (and thus in total three atria, whence the name)

A developmental defect of the aortic arch system in which the trachea and esophagus are completely encircled by connected segments of the aortic arch and its branches. This occurs if the normal process of regression and persistence of the bilateral embryonic aortic arches fails
Marked widening of the trachea and major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection
Marked widening of the major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection
The presence of an abnormally large pelvis
Over-sensitivity to certain frequency ranges of sound
Skin dimples are cutaneous indentations that are the result of tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) causing an indentation
A subtype of skin dimples occurring in the shoulder region
Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the uterus
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a gonad
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary system
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the genital system
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de las células de Leydig
Hipoplasia de las células de Leydig

trans-unit.source: Underdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone

trans-unit.target: Hiperplasia de las células de leydig

trans-unit.source: Hypertrophy or overdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone
A digit with two nails, with at least some soft tissue between them

trans-unit.target: Deterioro cognitivo para la construcción visuoespacial

trans-unit.source: Reduced ability affecting mainly visuospatial cognition which may be tested using pattern construction (for example by Differential Ability Scales, which test a person's strengths and weaknesses across a range of intellectual abilities)

A hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular neoplasm that arises almost exclusively in the central nervous system. Hemangioblastomas consist of a tightly packed cluster of small blood vessels forming a mass of up to 1 or 2 cm in diameter
Increased focal pigmentation of the vermilion of the lips
A neoplasm of the pineal gland
Lack of paramedian peaks and median notch of the upper lip vermilion

Reduced bulkiness of the crease or fold of skin running from the lateral margin of the nose, where nasal base meets the skin of the face, to a point just lateral to the corner of the mouth (cheilion or commissure)
#Nasolabial crease, hypoplastic #Nasolabial crease, underdeveloped #Nasolabial fold, hypoplastic
Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the skin surrounding the vermilion of the lips

trans-unit.target: Eversión del bermellón del labio superior

trans-unit.source: Inner aspect of the upper lip vermilion (normally apposing the teeth) visible in a frontal view, i.e., the presence of an everted upper lip

trans-unit.target: Bermellón labial con forma de V invertida

trans-unit.source: Triangular appearance of the oral aperture with the apex in the midpoint of the upper vermilion and the lower vermilion forming the base
#Inverted V-shaped upper lip #Tented mouth #Tented upper lip
Oral commissures positioned superior to the midline labial fissure

trans-unit.target: Bermellón del labio superior en forma de U

trans-unit.source: Gentle upward curve of the upper lip vermilion such that the center is placed well superior to the commissures
#Carp-like mouth #Carp-shaped mouth #Large, carp-shaped mouth #Wide, carp-shaped mouth
Visible space between the dental arches in occlusion
Tongue extending beyond the alveolar ridges or teeth at rest
Increased width of the uvula (subjective finding)
More than two clockwise hair whorls
#abnormal number of hair swirls #double crown (hair whorls) #extra hair swirls #extra hair whorl #supernumary hair swirls #supernumary hair whorl

trans-unit.target: Posición anormal del espiral del pelo

trans-unit.source: Hair growth from a single point on the scalp in any location other than lateral to the midline and close to the vertex of the skull
#abnormal location of hair swirl #abnormal position of hair whorl

A congenital, hairless plaque consisting of overgrown epidermis, sebaceous glands, hair follicles, apocrine glands and connective tissue. They are a variant of epidermal naevi. Sebaceous naevi most often appear on the scalp, but they may also arise on the face, neck or forehead. At birth, a sevaceous nevus typically appears as a solitary, smooth, yellow-orange hairless patch. Sebaceous naevi become more pronounced around adolescence, often appearing bumpy, warty or scaly
Epidermal naevi are due to an overgrowth of the epidermis and may be present at birth (50%) or develop during childhood
A type of nevus sebaceous with a linear form, raised borders and yellowish color
Generalized seizures with sustained increase in muscle contraction lasting a few seconds to minutes
Seizures characterized by a sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone, which may be fragmentary, confined to a segment (limb, jaw, head), or massive, leading to a slumping to the ground
A type of seizure characterized by crying or an outburst of crying as a major feature
A type of seizure characterized by laughing or an outburst of laughing as a major feature

A scintillating scotoma is a common visual aura that can preced a migraine, whereby a spot of flickering light near the center of the visual fields occurs. The spot prevents vision, and is thus termed scotoma. The scotoma can extend into one or more shimmering arcs of white or colored flashing lights
An overlap of the bony plates of the skull in an infant, with or without early closure
Abnormality of the fifth cranial nerve
trans-unit.target: Anomalía del v par craneal o trigémino

trans-unit.source: An abormality of the fifth cranial nerve
#Abnormality of the nervus trigeminus #Abnormality of the trigeminal nerve
Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve
Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve
Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve
trans-unit.target: Anomalía del xii par craneal o nervio hipogloso

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve
Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve
trans-unit.target: Anomalía del VII par craneal o nervio facial

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve sometimes also referred to as the facial nerve
A segmental myoclonus of muscles innervated by the facial nerve

trans-unit.target: Deterioro de la sensación de temperatura

trans-unit.source: A reduced ability to discriminate between different temperatures
#Abnormality of temperature sensation #Loss of temperature sensation
A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation). This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus
A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position

trans-unit.target: Alteración en la sensación de dolor

trans-unit.source: Pain is an unpleasant sensation that can range from mild, localized discomfort to agony, whereby the physical part of pain results from nerve stimulation and is often accompanied by an emotional component. This term groups abnormalities in pain sensation presumed to result from abnormalities related to the specific nerve fibers that carry the pain impulses to the brain
Spontaneous pain is a kind of neuropathic pain which occurs without an identifiable trigger

trans-unit.target: Cambios tróficos relacionados con el dolor

trans-unit.source: Trophic changes is a term used to describe abnormalities in the area of pain that include primarily wasting away of the skin, tissues, or muscle, thinning of the bones, and changes in how the hair or nails grow, including thickening or thinning of hair or brittle nails
A pattern of sensory loss with selective loss of touch sensation and proprioception without loss of pain and temperature, or vice-versa

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la homeostasis del cobre

trans-unit.source: A kind of Abnormality of copper homeostasis related to a decreased concentration of ceruloplasmin in the blood

trans-unit.target: Cobre sérico unido a nonceruloplasmina elevado

trans-unit.source: An increased concentration of non ceruloplasmin bound copper in the blood

trans-unit.target: Aumento de la concentración urinaria de cobre

trans-unit.source: An increased concentration of copper in the urine
A abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG) and being identified at multiple locations (foci)
Focal (localized) slow activity reflects focal dysfunction, not diffuse dysfunction (i.e., encephalopathy)
#EEG: focal slow activity #EEG: localised slow activity #EEG: localized slow activity
Multifocal slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
Diffuse slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
#EEG: generalised slow activity #EEG: generalized slow activity
EEG with persistent abnormal rhythmic activity
trans-unit.target: EEG con actividad rítmica anormal persistente

trans-unit.source: The presence of complexes of slow spikes and slow waves (<2.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG)

trans-unit.target: EEG con complejos punta-onda (2.5 a 3.5 hz)

trans-unit.source: The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (2.5-3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG)
The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (>3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG)

Complexes of spikes (<70 ms) and sharp waves (70-200 ms), which are sharp transient waves that have a strong association with epilepsy, in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)

trans-unit.target: EEG con trazado de supresión de actividad

trans-unit.source: The burst suppression pattern in electroencephalography refers to a characteristic periodic pattern of low voltage (<10 microvolts) suppressed background and a relatively shorter pattern of higher amplitude slow, sharp, and spiking complexes
EEG abnormalities (epileptiform discharges) evoked by flashing lights or black and white striped patterns
EEG with periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges
trans-unit.target: EEG con descargas epileptiformes periódicas lateralizadas

trans-unit.source: Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs)are periodic, lateralized, and epileptiform. PLEDs show a relatively constant interval between discharges (0.5 to 3 seconds)
EEG with generalized low amplitude activity
trans-unit.target: EEG con actividad generalizada de baja amplitud

trans-unit.source: An abnormal generalized reduction in amplitude of the cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
EEG with localized low amplitude activity
trans-unit.target: EEG con actividad localizada de baja amplitud

trans-unit.source: An abnormal localized reduction in amplitude of the cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
Periodically recurring abnormalities in the EEG

trans-unit.target: EEG con descargas epileptiformes inducidas por hiperventilación

trans-unit.source: Epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are extended
A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are flexed
A kind of breech presentation in which one or both hips are extended and one or both of the fetus' feet are pointing down and entering the birth canal

trans-unit.target: Retraso en el desarrollo de la motricidad fina

trans-unit.source: A type of motor delay characterized by an delay in acquiring the ability to control the fingers and hands
A delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others
Severe mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 20-34
#Early and severe mental retardation #Mental retardation, severe #Severe mental retardation

An enduring pattern of uncooperative, defiant, and hostile behavior toward authority figures that does not involve major antisocial violations, is not accounted for by the child's developmental stage, and results in significant functional impairment. A certain level of oppositional behavior is common in children and adolescents
An incomplete closure of the abdominal wall

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts
A type of dyssynergia affecting eye movements and characterized by the inability to smoothly follow a visual target across the visual field
A type of dyssynergy characterized by the lack of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed

Incoordination of movement caused by a deficit in the sensory nervous system. Sensory ataxia can be distinguished from cerebellar ataxia by asking the patient to close his or her eyes. Persons with cerebellar ataxia show only a minimal worsening of symptoms, whereas persons with sensory ataxia show a marked worsening of symptoms

trans-unit.target: Inversión de la onda T en el ECG

trans-unit.source: An inversion of the T-wave (which is normally positive)

trans-unit.target: Atrofia de la médula espinal a nivel cervical

trans-unit.source: Atrophy of the cervical segment of the spinal cord
The presence of xanthomas (intra-and extra-cellular accumulations of cholesterol) extensor tendons (typically over knuckles, Achilles tendon, knee, and elbows)

A diagnostic reflex elicited by stimulation of the skin over the surface of the lateral malleolus of the foot. The Chaddock refelx is present if there is extension of one or more or all of the toes with or without fanning of them when the external inframalleolar skin is stimulated. The Chaddock sign, similar to the Babinski sign, is taken to be an indication of disease of the spinocortical (pyramidal) tract

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad del nivel de proteínas circulantes

trans-unit.source: An abnormal level of a circulating protein in the blood
A type of strabismus in which only one eye is affected. Unilateral strabismus is to be distinguished from alternating strabismus, in which either of the eyes 'squints' at different times

The presence during the prenatal period of a cystic mass with multiple septa with multiple, asymmetric, thin-walled cysts near the posterior aspect of the neck. Fetal cystic hygroma can be defined as nuchal translucency with or without septations measuring greater than 3.0 mm

trans-unit.target: Aumento de la translucencia nucal fetal

trans-unit.source: The presence of an abnormally large hypoechoic space in the posterior fetal neck (usually detected on prenatal ultrasound examination)
An abnormality of the umbilical cord, which is the cord connecting the developing embryo or fetus to the placenta
A congenital disorder of the pulmonary valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop
A congenital disorder of the aortic valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop
Shortening of the extremities affecting primarily the distal parts of the limbs (hands and feet) in relation to the other segments of the limbs
A disease where there is cellular death (necrosis) of bone components due to interruption of the blood supply
#Aseptic bone necrosis #Avascular necrosis #Bone infarction #Ischemic bone necrosis #Osteochondronecrosis #Osteonecrosis

A joint disorder caused by blood deprivation in the subchondral bone causing the subchondral bone to die in a process called avascular necrosis. The bone is then reabsorbed by the body, leaving the articular cartilage it supported prone to damage. The result is fragmentation (dissection) of both cartilage and bone, and the free movement of these osteochondral fragments within the joint space, causing pain and further damage
Morbus Koehler is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os naviculare pedis
Morbus Kienboeck is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os lunatum

A 'coral-like' pattern of opacity in the lens of the eye. That is, a cataract with an irregular, stellate form
A form of cataract in which the lens substance has shrunk, leaving a collapsed, flattened capsule with little or no cortex or epithelium on the lens
A type of cataract affecting the Anterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the Lens capsule
A cataract that affects the posterior part of the cortex of the lens
A kind of nuclear cataract characterized by fiberglasslike or needlelike crystals projecting in different directions, through or close to the axial region of the lens

An abnormality of the nasal skeleton
An abnormality of the external nose
An abnormality of the nasal bone, comprising the left nasal bone and the right nasal bone
Absence or underdevelopment of the nasal bone

A finding of a focus of increased echogenicity upon prenatal ultrasound examination of the fetus. The foci may be present in one or both ventricles. Echogenic intracardiac focus (EICF) is defined as a focus of echogenicity comparable to bone, in the region of the papillary muscle in either or both ventricles of the fetal heart
Echogenic bowel is defined as fetal bowel with homogenous areas of echogenicity that are equal to or greater than that of surrounding bone
An abnormality of the renal pelvis

Mild pyelectasis is defined as a hypoechoic spherical or elliptical space within the renal pelvis that measures at least 5mm and not more than 10 mm. The measurement is taken on a transverse section through the fetal renal pelvis using the maximum anterior-to-posterior measurement
The presence of dilatation of the renal pelvis
Abnormality of ductus venosus blood flow
trans-unit.target: Anomalía del flujo sanguíneo del ductus venoso

trans-unit.source: An first-trimester prenatal ultrasound finding of abnormal blood flow in the ductus venosus
Abnormality of the fetal cardiovascular system
An abnormality of the fetal circulation system or fetal echocardiogram
Abnormality of umbilical vein blood flow
trans-unit.target: Anomalía del flujo sanguíneo de la vena umbilical

trans-unit.source: An first-trimester prenatal ultrasound finding of abnormal blood flow in the umbilical vein
An abnormality of the fourth ventricle
An abnormality of the third ventricle

A kind of ventriculomegaly occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (pmid:16100637)
A form of hydrocephalus in which the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the cerebral ventricular system or in the outlets of the CSF to the arachnoid space is obstructed
Underdevelopment of the right-sided structures of the heart
The presence of a dilated urinary bladder
Fetal megacystis is an abnormally enlarged bladder identified at any gestational age
A developmental defect resulting in an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra
A bilateral form of agenesis of the kidney
Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation of the lung
trans-unit.target: Malformación adenomatoidea quística congénita del pulmón

trans-unit.source: Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM) can be diagnosed prenatally if ultrasound shows a cystic or solid lung tumor. A CCAM does not have systemic arterial blood supply (in contrast to bronchopulmonary sequenstration). It is a cystic area within the lung that originates from abnormal embryogenesis
#CCAM #Congenital cystic disease of the lung #Cystic adenomatoid lung disease
The presence of microscopic cystic masses of nonfunctioning pulmonary tissue that lack an obvious communication with the tracheobronchial tree
A kind of bronchopulmonary sequestration that is incorporated into the normal surrounding lung
A kind of bronchopulmonary sequestration that is completely discrete from the normal lung and is surrounded by separate pleura
Absence of stomach bubble on fetal sonography
trans-unit.target: Ausencia de estómago en ecografía fetal

trans-unit.source: By the 14th week of gestation it is nearly always possible to visualized the fluid-filled fetal stomach bubble on prenatal sonography. This term refers to the absence of a normal fetal stomach bubble on fetal ultrasonography performed at around 16 to 20 weeks' gestation

A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of many (more than three) gene loci

A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of a few gene loci. It is recommended this term be used for traits governed by three loci, although it is noted that usage of this term in the literature is not uniform
A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of two gene loci
A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the sex chromosomes
An abnormality of the morphology or counts of the cells that make up the immune system
An abnormality of the extrinsic pathway (also known as the tissue factor pathway) of the coagulation cascade
An abnormality of the intrinsic pathway (also known as the contact activation pathway) of the coagulation cascade

trans-unit.target: Susceptibilidad aumentada a intercambio de cromátides hermanas

trans-unit.target: Aumento de la densidad mineral ósea

trans-unit.source: An abnormal increase of bone mineral density, that is, of the amount of matter per cubic centimeter of bones which is often refered to as osteosclerosis. Osteosclerosis can be detected on radiological examination as an increased whiteness (density) of affected bones
Abnormally increased formation of dense trabecular bone tissue. Despite the increased density of bone tissue, osteopetrotic bones tend to be more fracture-prone than normal
A severe form of myopia with greater than -6.00 diopters
#High myopia #Severe myopia (> -6.00 diopters) #Severe near sightedness #Severely close sighted #Severely near sighted

An abnormality of the systemic arterial tree, which consists of the aorta and other systemic arteries
A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of regenerative nodules of a variety of sizes

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the neck musculature

Sudden appearance of disease manifestations over a short period of time
Slow, creeping onset, slow progress and long continuance of disease manifestations
Somewhat rapid onset and change of disease manifestations

trans-unit.target: Dentinogénesis imperfecta limitada a los dientes primarios

trans-unit.source: Developmental dysplasia of dentin affecting only the primary dentition
