trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la morfología de los incisivos

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of morphology of the incisor tooth
The presence of an altered number of of the incisor teeth.
An abnormal conical morphology of the incisor tooth
The presence of a supernumerary tooth in the midline between the maxillary central incisors
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e., extra, tooth or teeth
An abnormality of morphology of molar tooth

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la morfología molar permanente

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of morphology of permanent molar
A developmental defect of tooth color
A localized form of developmental hypoplasia of the dental enamel
A tooth that has not erupted because of local impediments (overcrowding or fibrous gum overgrowth)
An abnormality of morphology of premolar tooth
Increased size of the incisor tooth
An abnormal conical morphology of the primary incisor
An abnormal conical morphology of either maxillary primary incisor tooth or maxillary permanent incisor tooth or both
A form of hypomineralization of enamel characterized by reduced calcification
A form of hypomineralization of enamel characterized by a chalky appearance of the enamel with orange, brown, or white color
Dentinogenesis imperfecta of primary and permanent teeth
trans-unit.target: Dentinogénesis imperfecta de los dientes primarios y permanentes

trans-unit.source: Developmental dysplasia of dentin or both the primary dentition and the permanent dentition
Talon cusp is an accessory cusp located near the cingulum (the portion of the lingual or palatal aspect of the tooth that forms a convex protuberance at the cervical third of the anatomic crown)
An abnormality of the incisor characterized by invagination of the enamel, giving a radiographic appearance that suggests a tooth within a tooth
A dental anomaly characterized by the presence of a two fused teeth
The union of two separately developing tooth germs typically leading to one less tooth than normal in the affected dental arch
The development of two teeth from a single tooth bud, leading to a larger fused tooth
Mulberry molars are irregular teeth generally affecting the first molars and are characterized by a grossly deformed crown imitating, as the name implies, the surface of a mulberry
Increased size and molar morphology of premolar tooth
Maxillary teeth cover the mandibular teeth when biting to an increased degree
An abnormal anteroposterior extension of the maxillary teeth beyond the plane of the mandibular teeth upon jaw closure
A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system
A sudden flexion, extension or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles which is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure

A type of apraxia that is characterized by difficulty or inability to execute speech movements because of problems with coordination and motor problems, leading to incorrect articulation. An increase of errors with increasing word and phrase length may occur
Unilateral paresis (weakness) with spasticity of the affected muscles and increased tendon reflexes
An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the intestine
An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the ileum
Abnormality of the left ventricular outflow tract
trans-unit.target: Anomalía del tracto de salida del ventrículo

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the outflow tract of the left ventricle

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la homeostasis del volumen sanguíneo

trans-unit.source: An abnormality in the amount of volume occupied by intravascular blood
An increase in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood
An decrease in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood
Recurrent episodes of ulceration of the oral mucosa
Abnormality of immune serum protein physiology
trans-unit.target: Alteración de la fisiología de proteínas séricas inmunitarias

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the concentration or function of circulating immune proteins

trans-unit.target: Alteración del nivel de citoquinas en suero

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the cytokine levels in the blood, i.e., an abnormality of any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells

trans-unit.target: Alteración de la secreción de citoquinas

trans-unit.source: An abnormality in the production or cellular release of a cytokine (i.e., any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells)

trans-unit.target: Producción anómala de citoquinas NFKB1 dependientes

trans-unit.source: An impairment in the production by leukocytes of NFKB1-dependent cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha and interferon-alpha

trans-unit.target: Alteración de la secreción de quimioquinas
Alteración de la secreción de interferón
Alteración de la secreción de interleuquina

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of tumor necrosis factor secretion
trans-unit.target: Alteración de la secreción del factor de necrosis tumoral

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the nasal dorsum, also known as the nasal ridge
Nasal ridge curving posteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de la morfología de la piel

trans-unit.source: Any morphological abnormality of the skin

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de la fisiología de la piel

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the physiological function of the skin
The presence of inflammation of the skin. That is, an abnormality of the skin resulting from the local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes
#Abnormal tendency to infections of the skin #Inflammatory skin disease #Skin inflammation

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de la morfología de la epidermis

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the morphology of the epidermis
An abnormality of the melanosomes, i.e., of the cellular organelles in which melanin pigments are synthesized and stored within melanocytes (the cells that produce pigment in the dermis)
A significant descent of the kidney as the patient moves from the supine to the erect position
A type of eczema that occurs in the lips and perioral area

A condition characterized by necrosis of the mucosal and submucosal layers of the esophagus not related to ingestion of caustic or other injurious agents. Endoscopically, there is a dark lesion ('black esophagus') distributed in a circumferential manner in the distal one-third of the esophagus with or without exudates. There is involvement of the distal esophagus ending sharply at the gastroesophageal junction
A bilateral form of fetal pyelectasis

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de la morfología del cáliz renal

trans-unit.source: Any abnormality of the morphology of the major calices or minor calices of the kidney
The presence of a rash (change of color and texture) of the perianal skin

A furuncle (boil) is a skin infection involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue. Chronic furunculosis refers to recurrent episodes of furuncles, often caused by recurrent staphylococcus infection

trans-unit.target: Aumento de la sensibilidad a la radiación ionizante

trans-unit.source: An abnormally increased sensitivity to the effects of ionizing radiation
Mild fever that does not exceed 38.5 degree centrigrade

trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de las glándulas sudoríparas

trans-unit.source: Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the sweat glands
Pale reddish slightly elevated papules and plaques of 0.5-3 cm in diameter and not accompanied by pruritus

trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de anexos de la piel

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the skin adnexa (skin appendages), which are specialized skin structures located within the dermis and focally within the subcutaneous fatty tissue, comprising three histologically distinct structures: (1) the pilosebaceous unit (hair follicle and sebaceous glands); (2) the eccrine sweat glands; and (3) the apocrine glands
Gastric duplication is a usually cystic malformation of gastrointestinal tract, usually attached to the greater curvature of the stomach and has no communication with the stomach
A spherical hollow structure with a smooth muscle coat, lined by a mucous membrane, and attached to any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the base of the tongue to the anus
A type of cataract (opacification of the lens) that forms during the course of aging

trans-unit.target: Catarata nuclear asociada con la edad

trans-unit.source: A type of age-related cataract that primarily affects the nucleus of the lens

trans-unit.target: Catarata cortical relacionada con la edad

trans-unit.source: A type of age-related cataract that primarily affects the cortex of the lens

trans-unit.target: Catarata subcapsular posterior asociada con la edad

trans-unit.source: A type of age-related cataract consisting of granular opacities occurring mainly in the central posterior cortex just under the posterior capsule
A seizure that occurs in the context of a brain insult (systemic, toxic, or metabolic) and may not recur when the underlying cause has been removed or the acute phase has elapsed
Typical absences are brief for seconds generalized epileptic seizures of abrupt onset and abrupt termination with impairment of consciousness

trans-unit.target: Crisis de ausencia con otras características especiales

trans-unit.source: Absence seizures that are characterized by additional motor phenomena such as eyelid myoclonias or myoclonic seizure of the upper limbs

trans-unit.target: Crisis de ausencia con mioclonías del párpado

trans-unit.source: Absence seizures that are additionally characterized by eyelid myoclonia
Absence seizures that are additionally characterized by rhythmic bilateral myoclonias of the arms and shoulders synchronous with EEG discharges, with additional tonic components of the arms
Atypical absence lasting for more than 30 minutes

trans-unit.target: Crisis de ausencia de aparición temprana

trans-unit.source: Typical absence seizures starting before the age of 4 years
Focal seizures involving musculature in any form

Focal seizures with an objectively documented and distinct alteration of autonomic nervous system function involving cardiovascular, pupillary, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor and thermoregularity functions
Focal autonomic seizures with altered responsiveness
trans-unit.target: Convulsiones autonómicas focales con respuesta alterada

trans-unit.source: An autonomic seizure with altered responsiveness
Focal autonomic seizures without altered responsiveness
trans-unit.target: Convulsiones autonómicas focales sin respuesta alterada

trans-unit.source: An autonomic seizure without altered responsiveness
Subjective ictal phenomena that, in a given patient, may precede observable seizures; if alone, constitute a if alone, constitute a simple partial seizure
Auras with sensations of buzzing, drumming sounds or single tones

Auras with abdominal discomfort including nausea, emptiness, tightness, churning, butterflies, malaise, pain, and hunger; sensation may rise to chest or throat. Some phenomena may reflect ictal autonomic dysfunction
Auras with taste sensations including acidic, bitter, salty , sweet or metallic tastes
Auras with sensation of odor, usually disagreeable
Auras with affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual phenomena including illusory or composite hallucinatory events
Auras with sensation of tingling, numbness, electric shock sensations, pain, sense of movement, or desire to move
A sensation consistent with involvement of the autonomic nervous system, including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor and thermoregulatory functions
Auras with sensation of flashing or flickering lights, spots, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis
Seizures with sustained increase in muscle contraction in parts of the body lasting a few seconds to minutes
Focal seizure with eyelid myoclonia, not eyelid myoclonias in the context of absence seizures
Seizures with regularly repetitive myoclonus, involving the same muscle groups, at a frequency of about 2-3 c/sec
Seizures with sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone with a preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting one to two seconds or more, involving head, trunk, jaw or limb musculature
Febrile seizures with generalized tonic-clonic semiology, duration less than 15 minutes, and without recurrence within the next 24 hours
Febrile seizures with focal semiology, duration of more than 15 minutes, or occurring in a cluster of 2 or more convulsions within 24 hours
Seizures with a decrease in amplitude and/or rate or arrest of ongoing motor activity

Seizures with increase in rate of ongoing movements or inappropriately rapid performance of a movement involving predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrashing, rocking movements
Tonic seizures with a sustained, forced conjugate ocular, cephalic and/or truncal rotation or lateral deviation from the midline
An EEG with constitutional variants contains waves that are rare or unusual but not generally pathologic

trans-unit.target: EEG con actividad de fondo de 4-5/ segundos
EEG con predominancia de ondas alfa

trans-unit.source: EEG dominated by diffuse beta-waves (>13 Hz)

trans-unit.target: EEG dominado por ondas beta difusas

trans-unit.source: EEG dominated by diffuse beta waves (>13 Hz) with occipitally localized alpha waves (8-13 Hz)
EEG with an amplitude less than 30 microvolts without observable occipital alpha rhythm (8-13 Hz)
Electroencephalographic patterns that resemble epileptogenic abnormalities
EEG with hyperventilation-induced focal epileptiform discharges
trans-unit.target: EEG con descargas epileptiformes focales inducidas por hiperventilación

trans-unit.target: Marcador menor en la ecografía fetal

trans-unit.source: An finding upon obstetric ultrasound examination performed at around 16 to 20 weeks of gestation that is abnormal but not clearly identifiable as a fetal anatomic malformation or growth restriction. Such findings are known as soft markers since they are associated with increased risk for fetal aneuploidy or other disorders

Fetal choroid plexus cysts (CPCs) are sonographically discrete, small cysts (3 mm or more) found in the choroid plexus within the lateral cerebral ventricles of the developing fetus at 14 to 24 weeks gestation. Imaging of the choroid plexus is performed in the transverse plane of the fetal head at the same level that the lateral cerebral ventricle is evaluated. The choroid plexus should be inspected bilaterally for the presence of cysts. The size of CPCs is not of clinical relevance (pmid:16100637)

The cisterna magna is measured on a transaxial view of the fetal head angled 15 degrees caudal to the canthomeatal line. The anterior/posterior diameter is taken between the inferior/posterior surface of the vemis of the cerebellum to the inner surface of the cranium. An enlarged cisternal magna is defined by an anterior/posterior diameter of 10 mm or more (pmid:16100637)

A short femur length is defined as either a measurement below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or a measurement that is less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The femur should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (pmid:16100637)

A short humerus length is defined as a length below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or as a measurement less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The humerus should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (pmid:16100637)

On prenatal ultrasound, the nasal bone is a thin echogenic line within the bridge of the fetal nose. The fetus is imaged facing the transducer with the fetal face strictly in the midline. The angle of insonation is 90 degrees, with the longitudinal axis of the nasal bone as the reference line. Calibres are placed at each end of the nasal bone. Absence of the nasal bone or measurements below 2.5th percentile are considered significant (pmid:16100637)

Fifth finger clinodactyly is defined by a hypoplastic or absent mid-phalanx of the fifth digit. Ultrasound identification of the fetal hand must first be undertaken and then appropriate magnification accomplished. The evaluation requires stretching of the 5 fingers. The diagnosis is established when the middle phalanx of the fifth finger is markedly smaller than normal or absent, which often causes the finger to be curved inward (pmid:16100637)
An abnormally high concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age
An abnormally high concentration of maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin as compared to normal values for gestational-age
An abnormally low concentration of maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin as compared to normal values for gestational-age
An abnormally low concentration of serum PAPP-A (pregnancy associated plasma protein A), as compared to normal values for gestational-age
An abnormally elevated or decreased level of a maternal serum marker analytes used in screening for aneuploidy

trans-unit.target: Alteración en las funciones mentales superiores

trans-unit.source: Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Ankle clonus is tested by rapidly flexing the foot upward
.Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Knee clonus can be tested by rapidly pushing the patella towards the toes
Microcephaly (HP:0000252) that is present already at the time of birth

#congenital decreased head circumference #congenital small head #congenital small head circumference #congenital small skull #decreased head circumference present at birth #Head circumference small for gestational age #microcephaly present at birth #small cranium present at birth #small head circumference present at birth #small head present at birth #small skull present at birth
Functional abnormality of the middle ear
An abnormality of the function of the middle ear
An abnormality of the incus, an ossicle in the middle ear
An abnormality of the malleus* (FMA:52753), an ossicle in the middle ear
This term refers to the loss of eyelashes that were previously present
The presence of a carcinoma of the esophagus
Onset of disease at up to 8 weeks of gestation
Onset prior to birth but after 8 weeks of gestation
Onset of disease at the age of between 16 and 40 years
Onset of disease at the age of between 1 and 5 years
A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the small intestine
A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the duodenum

trans-unit.target: Aplasia / hipoplasia de la vesícula biliar

trans-unit.source: Absence or underdevelopment of the gallbladder
A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form
#Agenesis of the gallbladder #Aplasia of the gallbladder
Sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic motor movements (spasms), involving the eyes and muscles of the face
Regurgitation of milk through the nose

trans-unit.target: Alimentación por sonda nasogástrica en la infancia

trans-unit.source: Feeding problem necessitating nasogastric tube feeding

trans-unit.target: Alimentación por sonda de gastrostomía en la infancia

trans-unit.source: Feeding problem necessitating gastrostomy tube feeding
Abnormality of small intestinal villus morphology
trans-unit.target: Anormalidad de la morfología de las vellosidades intestinales

trans-unit.source: The enteric villi are atrophic or absent
#Atrophy of small intestinal villi #Biopsy shows villous atrophy #Duodenal villous atrophy #Small intestine biopsy shows villous atrophy #Variable degree of villous atrophy

trans-unit.target: Discapacidad auditiva/hipoacusia bilateral mixta o neurosensorial de inicio en la infancia

trans-unit.source: Sensorineural hearing impairment with childhood onset
Persistence of the stapedial artery, which normally regresses during embryonic life
Complete loss of hearing related to a sensorineural defect
In primary position the Upbeat nystagmus beats upward. The associated oscillopsias are often very irritating, but the symptoms are usually transient
Absence of globe, optic nerve, chiasm and optic tracts. No evidence of ocular tissue on MRI scan or examination
An abnormality of the lacrimal punctum, an opening on the eyelid close to the medial canthus that drains tears from the conjunctival sac into the lacrimal duct in the same eyelid
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one eye
An abnormality of the lacrimal duct, a duct that drain tears from the conjunctiva, via the lacrimal puncta, into the lacrimal sac
Abnormality of the lacrimal gland, i.e., of the almond-shaped gland that secretes the aqueous layer of the tear film for each eye
Anterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
trans-unit.target: Sinequia anterior de la cámara anterior

trans-unit.source: Adhesions between the iris and the cornea
Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
trans-unit.target: Sinequias posteriores de la cámara anterior

trans-unit.source: Adhesions between the iris and the lens
Developmental abnormality in which the lens and cornea are not separated
An abnormal anteroposterior thickness of the cornea

trans-unit.target: Aumento de grosor de la córnea

trans-unit.source: A increased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea
Abnormality of the corneal endothelium, that is, the single layer of cells on the inner surface of the cornea

trans-unit.target: Anomalía de la membrana de Descemet

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of Descemet's membrane, which is the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium
Reduced number of corneal endothelial cells
trans-unit.target: Reducción del número de células endoteliales de la córnea

trans-unit.source: A reduction in the number of corneal endothelial cells
An abnormality of the stroma of cornea, also known as the substantia propria of cornea
Reduced transparency of the central portion of the corneal stroma
Generalized reduced transparency of the stroma of the cornea
Abnormality of the corneal epithelium, that is of the epithelial tissue that covers the front of the cornea
Ingrowth of new blood vessels into the cornea
New growth of vessels on the surface of the iris
A conical projection of the anterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly
A conical projection of the posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly
Progressive maculopathy characterized by concentric regions of hyper- and hypo-pigmentation
Cystoid macular edema (CME) is any type of macular edema that involves cyst formation
Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) is the creation of new blood vessels in the choroid layer of the eye
Pale often indistinct lesions of the macula
A macular hole is a small break in the macula, located in the center of the retina
Increased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea
Drusen (singular, 'druse') are tiny yellow or white accumulations of extracellular material (lipofuscin) that build up in Bruch's membrane of the eye
Splitting of the retina in the macular region
Increased amount of pigmentation of the retina

A benign tumor of the retina that appears as a grouping of blood-filled saccules within the inner retinal layers or on the surface of the optic disc. Retinal cavernous angioma are described as having a 'cluster of grapes' appearance
An abnormality of binocular vision, that is of the ability to synthesize the visual inputs from both eyes to a single image with perception of depth
Inability to make fine depth discriminations from parallax provided by the two eyes' different positions on the head
A condition where the retina contains no functional cone cells, so that in addition to the absence of color discrimination, vision in lights of normal intensity is difficult
The condition of having both rods and cones, but only a single kind of cone. Affected individuals have good pattern vision in daylight, but cannot distinguish between colors
Individuals affected by dichromacy possess only two types of cones, instead of three
Individuals with anomalous trichromacy possess three types of cones, but one of the three types of cones has an abnormal spectral sensitivity compared to normal cones

A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with abnormal M photopigment, such that the absorption spectrum is shifted toward L wavelengths. Affected individuals have difficulties distinguishing between red and green
Complete lack of the M photopigment, which is replaced with the L photopigment. Affected individuals tend to confuse red and green
Blue and green cones only; no functional red cones
An iris cyst is composed of a single cell layer of epithelium and is filled with fluid
Malignant tumor of melanocytes affecting the iris
A benign brown pigmented area over the iris representing proliferation of melanocyte cells in the stromal layer of the iris. An iris nevus can be flat or occasionally slightly elevated
An abnormal shape of the lens
Exaggerated curvature of the lens of the eye, producing an anterior or posterior spherical bulging
Solitary congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
trans-unit.target: Hipertrofia congénita aislada unilateral del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

trans-unit.source: Sharply demarcated hyperpigmentation which is congenital found in around 3-5% of the population and of no functional significance
#Single isolated CHRPE #Single isolated congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
Multiple bilateral congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
trans-unit.target: Hipertrofia congénita bilateral múltiple del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

trans-unit.source: Sharply demarcated hyperpigmentation which is congenital
A small break in the retina
A type of retinal exudate located in the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium

trans-unit.target: Degeneración de retina en copo de nieve

trans-unit.source: The appearance of yellow/white crystalline-like (hence the name) spots in the retina and thickening of the peripheral part of the vitreous
Abnormal spatial orientation of the cardiac segments
trans-unit.target: Orientación espacial anormal de los segmentos cardíacos

trans-unit.source: Abnormality of the spatial relationship of the atria to other components of the heart
Right atrial isomerism is characterized by bilateral triangular, morphologically right atrial, appendages, both joining the atrial chamber along a broad front with internal terminal crest
In left atrial isomerism there is a bilateral small finger-shaped morphologically left atrial appendage joining the atrial chamber along a narrow front without an internal terminal crest
Mirror image atrial arrangement, with morphologic right atrium on the left hand side and morphologic left atrium on the right hand side
Common atrium without defining morphologic features
Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries
trans-unit.target: Transposición corregida de las grandes arterias

trans-unit.source: The essence of the lesion is the combination of discordant atrioventricular and ventriculo-arterial connections. Thus, the morphologically right atrium is connected to a morphologically left ventricle across the mitral valve, with the left ventricle then connected to the pulmonary trunk. The morphologically left atrium is connected to the morphologically right ventricle across the tricuspid valve, with the morphologically right ventricle connected to the aorta
Crossing of the inflow streams of the two ventricles, due to an apparent twisting of the heart about its long axis
Criss-cross atrioventricular valves with superior-inferior ventricles
trans-unit.target: Válvulas auriculoventriculares criss-cross con ventrículos superior-inferior

trans-unit.source: Superior-inferior ventricles without criss-cross atrioventricular valves
trans-unit.target: Ventrículos superior-inferior sin válvulas auriculoventriculares entrecruzadas
Bucle en l del ventrículo derecho

trans-unit.source: Abnormal connection of the cardiac segments
trans-unit.target: Conexión anormal de los segmentos cardíacos

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the circulatory connection between atria and ventricles
Univentricular heart with absent left sided atrioventricular connection
trans-unit.target: Ventrículo único con ausencia de conexión atrioventricular del lado izquierdo

trans-unit.source: Biventricular heart with straddling right sided atrioventricular valve and absent left sided atrioventricular connection
trans-unit.target: Corazón biventricular con cabalgamiento entre la válvula atrioventricular derecha parcial y ausencia de conexión atrioventricular del lado izquierdo

trans-unit.source: Right sided atrium to left ventricle and absent left sided atrioventricular connection
trans-unit.target: Lado derecho de la aurícula al ventrículo izquierdo y conexión atrioventricular del lado izquierdo ausente

trans-unit.source: With left or right cardiac isomerism in a biventricular, the atrioventricular connections are perforce ambiguous, in that one of the connections is concordant (e.g., right-sided morphologic right atrium connected to a morphologic right ventricle) and one of the connections is discordant (e.g., left-sided morphologic right atrium connected to a morphologic left ventricle)
Connection of the right atrium to the left ventricle and of the left atrium to the right ventricle in a biventricular heart
The condition in which both atria are joined to a single ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve

The condition in which both atria are joined to the left ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually there is a hypoplastic right ventricle, which may be on the opposite side of the heart as usual
The condition in which both atria are joined to the right ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually, the left ventricle is hypoplastic
Double inlet to single ventricle of indeterminate morphology
trans-unit.target: Entrada doble al ventrículo único de morfología indeterminada

trans-unit.source: The condition in which both atria are joined to a single ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. The morphology of this ventricle does not allow one to determine if it corresponds to the left or right ventricle
Double inlet to single ventricle with common atrioventricular orifice
trans-unit.target: Entrada doble al ventrículo único con orificio atrioventricular común

trans-unit.source: Double inlet to single ventricle with two atrioventricular valves
trans-unit.target: Entrada doble al ventrículo único con dos válvulas auriculoventriculares

trans-unit.source: A congenital defect with failure to open of the mitral valve orifice
An atrioventricular valve that empties into both ventricles. The valve overrides the interventricular septum above a ventricular septum defect
Anomalous insertion of the chordae tendinae or papillary muscles into the contralateral ventricle in the presence of a ventricular septum defect

Anomalous mitral valve arcade is diagnosed b ased on the following features (1) An adequately sized mitral valve orifice; (2) short, thick, and poorly differentiated chordae with direct union of the papillary muscles to the anterior leaflet; (3) narrow or nearly nonexistent spaces between the abnormal chordae; and (4) greater differentiation of the chordae attached to the posterior papillary muscle
Complete absence of the interatrial septum with common atrioventricular valve and two atrioventricular connections

A congenital anomaly with partitioning of the right atrium to form a triatrial heart caused by persistence of the right valve of the sinus venosus. Typically, the right atrial partition is due to exaggerated fetal eustachian and thebesian valves, which together form an incomplete septum across the lower part of the atrium. This septum may range from a reticulum to a substantial sheet of tissue

trans-unit.target: Seno venoso del defecto septal atrial

trans-unit.source: An interatrial communication caused by a deficiency of the common wall between the superior vena cava (SVC) and the right-sided pulmonary veins. SVASD is commonly associated with anomalous pulmonary venous connection (APVC) of some or all of the pulmonary veins, which produces additional left-to-right shunting

trans-unit.target: Orificio de la válvula mitral doble

trans-unit.source: The left atrio-ventricular connection consists of two anatomically distinct orifices separated by accessory fibrous tissue

trans-unit.target: Velo anterior hendido de la válvula mitral

trans-unit.source: Cleft in the anterior mitral valve leaflet not associated with an atrioventricular canal defect
Abnormality of the mitral valve apparatus, whereby chordae attach to a single papillary muscle or hypoplastic papillary muscles
A congenital stenotic mitral valvular anomaly with a ring of tissue above the mitral valve
Congenital defect characterized by underdevelopment of the tricuspid valve
An atrioventricular valve that has failed to open (atretic)
An tricuspid valve that has failed to open (atretic)
A specific combination of heart defects with a primum atrial septal defect, cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet, and inlet ventricular defect. There is one valve annulus and two valve orifices

A specific combination of heart defects including a primum atrial septal defect and cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet. There is not an inlet ventricular septal defect present. There are two valve annuluses and two valve orifices

A specific combination of heart defects with a primum atrial septal defect, cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet, and an inlet ventricular septal defect. There are two valve annuli and two valve orifices

Anatomic features of unbalanced atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) include varying amounts of ventricular hypoplasia, as well as malalignment of the atrioventricular junction. In complete AVSD, the common AV valve can be situated either equally over the right and left ventricles (balanced) or unequally over the ventricles (unbalanced)
Short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve
trans-unit.target: Cuerdas tendinosas cortas de la válvula mitral

trans-unit.source: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve
A congenital defect of heart development characterized by origin of both pulmonary artery and aorta from the morphological left ventricle
Displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and into the abdomen
A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region and withouta defect of the sternum
A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region with a defect of the superior portion of the sternum
Congenital malformation of the thoracic wall with partial or total displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity. This feature is associated with sternal cleft or absence of the sternum
Congenital malformation of the ventral wall with partial or total evisceration of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and displacement partially into the abdominal cavity
Abnormal branching pattern of the aortic arch
trans-unit.target: Patrón de ramificación anormal del arco aórtico

trans-unit.source: A deviance from the norm of the origin or course of the right brachiocephalic artery, the left common carotid artery, the left subclavian artery or the proximal vertebral arteries
The aortic arch extends into the soft tissues of the neck before turning down into to become the descending aorta
Common origin of the right brachiocephalic artery and left common carotid artery
trans-unit.target: Origen común del tronco braquiocefálico derecho y la arteria carótida común izquierda

trans-unit.source: The left common carotid artery has a common origin with the innominate artery

A conenital abnormality of the aortic arch in which the two embryonic aortc arches form a vascular ring that surrounds the trachea or esophagus and then join to form the descending aorta. Double aortic arch can cause symptoms because of compression of the esophagus (dysphagia, cyanosis while eating) or trachea (stridor)
Left aortic arch with cervical origin of the right subclavian artery
trans-unit.target: Arco aórtico izquierdo con origen cervical de la arteria subclavia derecha

trans-unit.source: Left aortic arch with isolated subclavian artery
trans-unit.target: Arco aórtico izquierdo con arteria subclavia aislada

trans-unit.source: The subclavian artery arises from ductus arteriosus. While the ductus arteriosus is patent its blood supply comes from the ductus, hence from the pulmonary artery. After it closes, the blood supply is retrogradely from the vertebral artery via the circle of Willis
Left aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
trans-unit.target: Arco aórtico izquierdo con divertículo retroesofágica de Kommerell

trans-unit.source: A patent ductus arteriosus or ductal ligament completes the ring
Right aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
trans-unit.target: Arco aórtico derecho con divertículo retroesofágico de Kommerell

trans-unit.source: Aortic arch crosses the right mainstem bronchus. The left carotid artery is the first branch, right carotid artery the second branch and right subclavian artery as the third branch
Left aortic arch with retroesophageal right subclavian artery
trans-unit.target: Arco aórtico izquierdo con arteria subclavia retroesofágica derecha

trans-unit.source: Aortic arch crosses the left mainstem bronchus. The first branch is the right carotid artery, the second branch is the left carotid artery, the third branch is the subclavian artery, the fourth branch is the right subclavian artery arising from the posteromedial aspect of the distal aortic arch and continuing posterior to the esophagus to the right hand side of the body
Left aortic arch with right descending aorta and right ductus arteriosus
trans-unit.target: Arco aórtico izquierdo con aorta descendente derecha y de ductus arterioso derecho

trans-unit.source: The ring may be completed by the ductal ligament
Right aortic arch with left descending aorta and left ductus arteriosus
trans-unit.target: Arco aórtico derecho con aorta descendente izquierda y ductus arterioso izquierdo

trans-unit.source: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal left subclavian artery
trans-unit.target: Arco aórtico derecho con arteria subclavia izquierda retroesofágica

trans-unit.source: #Right aortic arch with aberrant left subclavian artery #Right aortic arch with anomalous left subclavian artery
Mesocardia is a abnormal location of the heart in which the heart is in a midline position and the longitudinal axis of the heart lies in the mid-sagittal plane

trans-unit.target: Dirección anormal del ápice del ventrículo

trans-unit.source: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex. Left sided is normal

trans-unit.target: Apex ventricular direccionado a la derecha

trans-unit.source: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex towards the right. Left sided is normal

trans-unit.target: Apex ventricular en dirección a la linea media

trans-unit.source: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex in the midline. Left sided is normal
Congenital malformation of the great arteries
trans-unit.target: Malformaciones congénitas de las grandes arterias

trans-unit.source: A congenital anomaly with an abnormal connection between the aorta and the main pulmonary artery resulting in an aortopulmonary shunt
Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect
trans-unit.target: Transposición corregida de las grandes arterias con comunicación interventricular

trans-unit.source: Transposition of the great arteries with intact ventricular septum
trans-unit.target: Transposición de grandes vasos con septo íntegro

trans-unit.source: Transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect
trans-unit.target: Transposición de grandes vasos con comunicación interventricular

trans-unit.source: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with each pulmonary artery arising separate from each other on the posterior or lateral aspect of the truncus

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby one of the two pulmonary artery branched does not arise from the common pulmonary trunk, but instead from the ductus arteriosus or directly from the aorta

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby the aortic arch is hypoplastic or interrupted, and a large patent ductus arteriosus is present
Non-continuity of the arch of aorta with an atretic point or absent segment

trans-unit.target: Interrupción del arco aórtico tipo a

trans-unit.source: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment at the level of the isthmus

trans-unit.target: Interrupción del arco aórtico tipo b

trans-unit.source: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment between the left carotid and subclavian arteries

trans-unit.target: Interrupción del arco aórtico tipo c

trans-unit.source: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment between the innominate and left carotid arteries

An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, which is defined by characteristics such as the number of lobes per lung and the relationship of the pulmonary arteries to their bronchi
Mirror image arrangement of the mainstem bronchi with the right pulmonary artery posterior to the right upper lobe bronchus and the left pulmonary artery anterior to the left upper lobe bronchus
An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which the morphology of both left and right lungs is the same
Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic right lungs
trans-unit.target: Situs ambiguo pulmonar (heterotaxia) con pulmones trilobulados bilaterales (2 pulmones derechos)

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which both lungs have the morphology of a right lungs
Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic left lungs
trans-unit.target: Situs ambiguo pulmonar (heterotaxia) con pulmones bilobulados bilaterales (2 pulmones izquierdos)

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which both lungs have the morphology of a left lung
An abnormality of the abdominal situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the abdomin and its organs

A type of ventricular septal defect communicating directly between the left ventricle and right atrium. This is anatomically possible because the normal tricuspid valve is more apically displaced than the mitral valve
.A ventricular septal defect that involves the inlet of the right ventricular septum immediately inferior to the AV valve apparatus
#Atrioventricular canal type ventricular septal defect #Type 3 ventricular septal defect

The trabecular septum is the largest part of the interventricular septum. It extends from the membranous septum to the apex and superiorly to the infundibular septum. A defect in the trabecular septum is called muscular VSD if the defect is completely rimmed by muscle
#Type 4 ventricular septal defect #Ventricular septal defect, muscular
A muscular ventricular septal defect located at the apex of the heart

trans-unit.target: Múltiples defectos del tabique interventricular muscular

trans-unit.source: Right pulmonary venous return to the inferior vena cava
Aorto-ventricular tunnel is a congenital, extracardiac channel which connects the ascending aorta above the sinutubular junction to the cavity of the left, or (less commonly) right ventricle
A developmental defect of the pericardium with congenital onset
No pericardium around the heart, occurring as a congenital defect, not the result of a surgical pericardectomy
No pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart
Complete right sided absence of pericardium
trans-unit.target: Ausencia completa de pericardio del lado derecho

trans-unit.source: No pericardium is present on the righthand side of the heart. It is a congenital absence of pericardium rather than the result of a pericardectomy
Partial right sided absence of pericardium
trans-unit.target: Ausencia de pericardio derecho diafragmático parcial

trans-unit.source: A congenital anomaly with lack of part of the pericardium on the righthand side of the heart
Complete left sided absence of pericardium
trans-unit.target: Ausencia completa de pericardio del lado izquierdo

trans-unit.source: A congenital anomaly with complete lack of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart
Partial left sided absence of pericardium
trans-unit.target: Ausencia de pericardio izquierdo diafragmático parcial

trans-unit.source: A congenital anomaly with lack of part of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart
Lack of a part of the pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart
Abnormal origin of the coronary arteries
trans-unit.target: Origen anormal de las arterias coronarias

trans-unit.source: Isolated abnormalities of the coronary artery origins. This may be in associated with other structural heart malformations but not the patterns of complex structural heart malformations which result in abnormal course of the coronary arteries
Anomalous origin of coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
trans-unit.target: Origen anómalo de la arteria coronaria desde arteria pulmonar

trans-unit.source: A coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta
Anomalous origin of left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
trans-unit.target: Origen anómalo de la arteria coronaria izquierda desde la arteria pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Left main coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the left cusp of the aortic valve
Anomalous origin of right coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
trans-unit.target: Origen anómalo de la arteria coronaria derecha de la arteria pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Right coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the right cusp of the aortic valve
The presence of a single coronary artery ostium from which both coronary arteries arise
A congenital malformation with abnormal connection between one of the coronary arteries and a heart chamber or another blood vessel

An abnormality of the coronary sinus, which is formed by the union of the great cardiac vein and the left marginal vein and terminates in the right atrium. The coronary sinus functions to o collect deoxygenated blood from the myocardium of the heart and drain it into the right atrium

trans-unit.target: Defecto septal atrial del seno coronario

trans-unit.source: An atrial septal defect characterized by a deficiency in the tissue separating the coronary sinus from the left atrium (LA). This results in partial or complete unroofing of the coronary sinus leading to a predominantly left-to-right shunt through the coronary sinus (LA to coronary sinus to right atrium [RA]). The orifice of the ostium is frequently large because of the increased flow. From the RA side, the defect is located at the level of the coronary sinus ostium and may also include some deficiency in atrial tissue around the ostium. From the LA side, the size can be variable depending on the degree of unroofing of the coronary sinus
A venous pouch within the left ventricular wall, with a neck opening into the coronary sinus
Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the juxtaductal region of aortic arch
Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized distal to the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the postductal region of aortic arch
Patent ductus arteriosus after birth at term
trans-unit.target: Ductus arterioso permeable después del nacimiento a término

trans-unit.source: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus in postnatal life when birth was at 37 completed weeks of gestation or greater
Patent ductus arteriosus after premature birth
trans-unit.target: Ductus arterioso permeable después del nacimiento prematuro

trans-unit.source: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus when birth was at less than 37 weeks completed gestation
The presence of both a left and a right ductus arteriosus
Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Doble salida ventricular derecha con doblemente comprometida defecto septal ventricular y estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Doble salida ventricular derecha con doblemente comprometida defecto septal ventricular sin estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Doble salida ventricular derecha con la no-comprometida defecto septal ventricular y estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Doble salida ventricular derecha con la no-comprometida defecto septal ventricular sin estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Doble salida ventricular derecha con comunicación interventricular subaórtica y estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Doble salida ventricular derecha con comunicación interventricular subaórtica sin estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Doble salida ventricular derecha con comunicación interventricular subpulmonar y estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Doble salida ventricular derecha con subpulmonar defecto septal ventricular sin estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve
trans-unit.target: Tetralogía de Fallot con válvula pulmonar ausente

trans-unit.source: Features of tetralogy of Fallot with either rudimentary ridges or the complete absence of pulmonic valve tissue
#Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve syndrome
Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
trans-unit.target: Origen anómalo de una arteria pulmonar desde la aorta ascendente

trans-unit.source: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from the ascending aorta with the contralateral pulmonary artery arising from the right ventricle
Anomalous origin of left pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
trans-unit.target: Origen anómalo de la arteria pulmonar izquierda desde la aorta ascendente

trans-unit.source: The left pulmonary artery originates from the ascending aorta in the presence of a pulmonary valve and main pulmonary artery
Failure to develop of the tricuspid valve and thus lack of the normal connection between the right atrium and the right ventricle
Right ventricular dysfunction (global or regional) with functional and morphological right ventricular abnormalities, with or without left ventricular disease

trans-unit.target: Cardiomiopatía no compactada de ventrículo izquierdo

trans-unit.source: Left ventricular non-compaction (LVNC) is characterized by prominent left ventricular trabeculae and deep inter-trabecular recesses. The myocardial wall is often thickened with a thin, compacted epicardial layer and a thickened endocardial layer. In some patients, LVNC is associated with left ventricular dilatation and systolic dysfunction, which can be transient in neonates

Transient left ventricular apical ballooning syndrome or takotsubo cardiomyopathy is characterized by transient regional systolic dysfunction involving the left ventricular apex and/or mid-ventricle in the absence of obstructive coronary disease on coronary angiography. Patients present with an abrupt onset of angina-like chest pain, and have diffuse T-wave inversion, sometimes preceded by ST-segment elevation, and mild cardiac enzyme elevation

Absence of the right superior vena cava (RSVC). An absent RSVC is always associated with a persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC). During normal fetal development, the left-sided anterior venous cardinal system regresses, leaving the coronary sinus (CS) and the ligament of Marshall. Failure of the closure of the left anterior cardinal vein results in PLSVC. In general, PLSVC is associated with the right superior vena cava (RSVC) and drains into the RA via a dilated CS. When developmental arrest occurs at an earlier stage, the CS is absent and the PLSVC drains into the left atrium
Bilateral superior vena cava with bridging vein
trans-unit.target: Vena cava superior con vena cabalgada bilateral

trans-unit.source: Bilateral superior vena cava with no bridging vein
trans-unit.target: Vena cava superior sin vena cabalgada bilateral

trans-unit.source: Left superior vena cava draining directly to the left atrium
trans-unit.target: Vena cava superior izquierda drenando directamente a la aurícula izquierda

trans-unit.source: Left superior vena cava draining to coronary sinus
trans-unit.target: Vena cava superior izquierda drenando al seno coronario

trans-unit.source: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation
trans-unit.target: Interrupción de la vena cava inferior con continuación ácigos

trans-unit.source: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation is the result of connection failure between the right subcardinal vein and the right vitelline vein. Consequently, venous blood from the caudal part of the body reaches the heart via the azygous vein and superior vena cava

A myxoma (tumor of primitive connective tissue) of the heart. Cardiac myxomas consist of stellate to plump, cytologically bland mesenchymal cells set in a myxoid stroma. Cardiac myxomas are of endocardial origina and general project from the endocardium into a cardiac chamber
Abnormal proliferation of blood vessels within the cardiac cavities attached to the endocardium

A teratoma within the heart. Most commonly, these tumors are detected in the pericardial cavity attached to the pulmonary artery and aorta. The tumour size within the heart varies from 2 to 9 cm in diameter, and intrapericardial tumors as large as 15 cm have been reported. Intracardiac tumors arise from the atrial or ventricular wall as nodular masses protruding into the cardiac chambers. Cardiac and pericardial teratomas are easily detected in the fetus and neonate by two-dimensional echocardiography as heterogeneous and encapsulated cystic masses. Histologically, cardiac teratomas contain multiple immature elements including epithelium, neuroglial tissue, thyroid, pancreas, smooth and skeletal muscle, cartilage and bone

Any cardiac rhythm other than the normal sinus rhythm. Such a rhythm may be either of sinus or ectopic origin and either regular or irregular. An arrhythmia may be due to a disturbance in impulse formation or conduction or both

#Abnormal electrocardiogram #Abnormality of cardiac conduction #Arrhythmias #Cardiac arrhythmia #Cardiac arrhythmias #Cardiac conduction abnormalities #Cardiac conduction defects #Cardiac rhythm disturbances #ECG abnormality #Ekg abnormalities #EKG abnormality #Electrocardiographic changes #Heart rhythm disorders #Irregular heart beat #Irregular heartbeat
Tetralogy of Fallot with absent subarterial conus
trans-unit.target: Tetralogía de Fallot con cono subarterial ausente

trans-unit.source: Tetralogy of Fallot with atrioventricular canal defect
trans-unit.target: Tetralogía de Fallot con defecto del canal atrioventricular

trans-unit.source: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia and major aortopulmonary collateral arteries
trans-unit.target: Tetralogía de Fallot con atresia pulmonar y arterias colaterales aortopulmonares

trans-unit.source: A type of tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia in which all pulmonary blood flow is derived from major aortopulmonary collateral arteries (MAPCA)
Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary stenosis
trans-unit.target: Tetralogía de Fallot con estenosis pulmonar

trans-unit.source: The commonest form of tetralogy of Fallot characterized by pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septum defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy, without pulmonary atresia, absent pulmonary valve, atrioventricular canal defect or absent subarterial conus
A ventricular septal defect that lies beneath the semilunar valve(s) in the conal or outlet septum
#Conal ventricular septal defect #Doubly committed ventricular septal defect #Infundibular ventricular septal defect #Supracristal ventricular septal defect #Type 1 ventricular septal defect
A ventricular septal defect that is confluent with and involves the membranous septum and is bordered by an atrioventricular valve, not including the type 3 VSDs
#Conoventricular ventricular septal defect #Membranous ventricular septal defect #Paramembranous ventricular septal defect #Type 2 ventricular septal defect #Ventricular septal defect, perimembranous
Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that is small enough to restrict flow across it such that a pressure gradient exists between the two sides of the VSD
Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that does not restrict flow across it sufficiently to generate a pressure gradient between the two sides of the VSD
The superior vena cava passes below the aortic arch

trans-unit.target: Recorrido anormal de la arteria coronaria

trans-unit.source: An abnormal path of a coronary artery
A type of supraventricular tachycardia that originates in the atrioventricular node
Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con conexión mediada vía accesoria

trans-unit.source: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory connection
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con conexión accesoria oculta
Taquicardia reciproca permanente de la unión

trans-unit.source: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the left free wall
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con vía accesoria oculta en la pared libre izquierda

trans-unit.source: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the right free wall
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con vía accesoria oculta en la pared libre derecha

trans-unit.source: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the septum
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con vía accesoria oculta en el tabique

trans-unit.source: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con vía accesoria manifiesta

trans-unit.source: Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the cerebellum
Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the left free wall
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con vía accesoria manifiesta en la pared libre izquierda

trans-unit.source: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the right free wall
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con vía accesoria manifiesta en la pared libre derecha

trans-unit.source: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the septum
trans-unit.target: Taquicardia supraventricular con vía accesoria manifiesta en el tabique

trans-unit.source: Abnormal electrophysiology of sinoatrial node origin
trans-unit.target: Electrofisiología anormal del origen del nodo sinusal

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium. THe SA node acts as the pacemaker of the heart
Delay of conduction through the atrioventricular node, which is manifested as prolongation of the PR interval in the electrocardiogram (EKG). All atrial impulses reach the ventricles

An intermittent atrioventricular block with failure of some atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles, i.e., some but not all atrial impulses are conducted through the atrioventricular node and trigger ventricular contraction

Progressive PR interval prolongation with the subsequent occurrence of a single nonconducted P wave that results in a pause. The pause that follows the nonconducted impulse is less than fully compensatory (less than the sum of two normal sinus intervals)
A type of second degree atrioventricular (AV) block characterized by sudden failure to conduct an impulse through the AV node without a preceding change in the PR interval

Atrioventricular (AV) dissociation is present if the atria and the ventricles are under the control of two separate pacemakers. AV dissociation can occur is the absence of a primary AV conduction disturbance
Block of conduction of electrical impulses along the Bundle of His or along one of its bundle branches
Conduction block in the anterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His

A conduction block of the right branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a prolongation of the QRS complex (greater than 0.12 s) with delayed activation of the right ventricle and terminal delay on the EKG
A conduction block of the left branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a generalized disturbance of QRS morphology on EKG
Libman-Sacks valvular lesions are sterile fibrofibrinous vegetations that favor the left-sided heart valves and usually form on the ventricular surface of the mitral valve
Abnormal conduction in all three divisions of the intraventricular conducting tissue
An abnormality of the pulmonary veins
Supracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
trans-unit.target: Conexión anómala total de venas pulmonares supracardíaca

trans-unit.source: Type 1 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
trans-unit.target: Conexión anómala total de venas pulmonares cardiacas

trans-unit.source: Type 2 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
trans-unit.target: Conexión infracardiaca anómala total de venas pulmonares

trans-unit.source: Type 3 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Mixed total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
trans-unit.target: Conexión anómala total de venas pulmonares mixta

trans-unit.source: Type 4 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Congenital malformation of the right heart

Systemic desaturation of a liveborn baby resulting from persistent pulmonary hypertension with a patent ductus arteriosus and patent foramen ovale, such that the circulation in postnatal life follows the fetal course
Clonus at the elbow joint, i.e., an exaggerated phasic stretch reflex characterized by repetitive, rhythmic contractions at the elbow, generated by rapid passive stretch at the elbow joint
An abnormality in the range and ease of motion of joints across their normal range

trans-unit.target: Alteración en la función sensorial central

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of cortical sensation. Assuming the primary sensory modalities are intact and the patient is alert and cooperative, the presence of an abnormality of sensory function usually indicates a lesion of a parietal cortex or of the thalamocortical projections to the parietal cortex

trans-unit.target: Alteración del nivel plasmático de cortisol

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the concentration of cortisol in the blood
Any structural anomaly of the adrenal glands
A functional abnormality of the adrenal glands
A form of adrenal insufficiency related to a lack of ACTH, which leads to a decrease in the production of cortisol by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone production is not usually affected

trans-unit.target: Insuficiencia suprarrenal por déficit de adrenocorticotropina (ACTH)

trans-unit.source: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in ACTH production
A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by a defect within the adrenal gland

trans-unit.target: Insuficiencia suprarrenal por déficit de hormona liberadora de corticotropina (CRH)

trans-unit.source: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in corticotropin-releasing hormone production

trans-unit.target: Déficit del receptor de hormona liberadora de corticotropina (CRHR)

trans-unit.source: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in the corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor
A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone can be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone
#Familial primary hyperaldosteronism type 1 #Glucocorticoid-remediable familial primary aldosteronism

trans-unit.target: Hiperaldosteronismo primario no sensible a glucocorticoides

trans-unit.source: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone cannot be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone or similar glucocorticoids
A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by abnormally increased renin levels
Abnormal anatomical location of the adrenal gland
Absent development of the adrenal gland
Hypercortisolemia associated with a overproduction of ACTH (often from a tumor), leading secondarily to overproduction of cortisol
An hormonally inactive adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that does not secrete excessive amounts of adrenal hormones
An hormonally active adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that secretes excessive amounts of adrenal hormones
An abnormality of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
A reduced ability to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), a hormone that stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete of glucocorticoids such as cortisol
Overproduction of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which generally leads secondarily to overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal cortex
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
An abnormality of the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis
The presence of a neoplasm (tumour) in the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis
Abnormal development of the neurohypophysis during embryonic growth and development

A solid, low grade, spindle cell, glial neoplasm of adults that originates in the neurohypophysis or infundibulum. Clinical signs and symptoms include visual disturbance, headache and features of hypopituitarism. Pituicytomas are well-circumscribed, solid masses that can measure up to several centimeters. Histologically, they show a compact architecture consisting of elongate, bipolar spindle cells arranged in interlacing fascicles or assuming a storiform pattern

An abnormal anatomical location of the posterior lobe of the hypophysis, also known as the neurohypophysis. The posterior pituitary is normally present in the dorsal portion of the sella turcica, but when ectopic is usually near the median eminence. This defect is likely to be due to abnormal migration during embryogenesis
Absence of the neurohypophysis owing to a developmental defect

trans-unit.target: Adenoma acidófico de células madre hipofisarias

trans-unit.source: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces gonadotropins

trans-unit.target: Adenoma hipofisario de células secretoras de hormona de crecimiento

trans-unit.source: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces grwoth hormone
A type of pituitary adenoma that is of unknown cellular origin and that lacks immunocytochemical or fine structural markers. Null cell adenomas are not associated with hormone excess
#Clinically silent pituitary adenoma #Hormonally silent pituitary adenoma #Non-functional pituitary adenoma #Silent pituitary adenoma
A type of pituitary adenoma that produces thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)

A pituitary tumor with subarachnoid, brain, or systemic metastasis. The diagnosis of a pituitary carcinoma requires evidence of metastatic disease, either outside the central nervous system (CNS) or as separate noncontiguous foci within the CNS

A spindled-to-epithelioid, oncocytic, nonendocrine neoplasm of the anterior hypophysis that manifests in adults and follows a benign clinical course. Pituitary spindle cell oncocytomas are firm, fibrous, and adherent to surrounding structures and are highly vascular
A structural abnormality of the parathyroid gland
A functional abnormality of the parathyroid gland
Abnormal embryonic development of the parathyroid gland
An abnormal anatomical location of the parathyroid gland

A type of hyperparathyroidism that occurs following kidney transplantation, which is a treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Although kidney transplantation leads to a normalization of serum calcium and parathyroid hormone in most patients. The state of persistent hypercalcemia and hyperparathyroidism is referred to as tertiary hyperparathyroidism
A type of hypoparathyroidism with circulating antiparathyroid or anti-calcium sensing receptor antibodies indicative of autoimmunity

trans-unit.target: Alteración de la morfología del tiroides

trans-unit.source: A structural abnormality of the thyroid gland
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to a singular nodule in the thyroid gland
Absence of a lobe of the thyroid gland related to a failure of its embryologic development
An abnormal growth of parafollicular (C-cells) cells
Thyrotoxicosis with toxic single thyroid nodule
trans-unit.target: Tirotoxicosis con nódulo tiroideo único tóxico

trans-unit.source: A type of hypothyroidism due to an insufficient stimulation of an otherwise normal thyroid gland. Central hypothyroidism is caused by either pituitary (secondary hypothyroidism) or hypothalamic (tertiary hypothyroidism) defects
An elevated concentration of 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine in the blood

trans-unit.target: Déficit del receptor de la hormona estimulante de la tiroides (TSHR)
Déficit del receptor de la hormona estimulante de la tiroides (TSHR) defecto
Déficit del receptor de la hormona estimulante del tiroides (TSHR)

trans-unit.source: Neoplasm categorized according to type of histological abnormality
Neoplasm categorized according to the anatomical site of origin of the neoplasm
The presence of an embryonal neoplasm of the kidney that primarily affects children
Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney, anywhere within a renal lobe (a portion of a kidney consisting of a renal pyramid and the renal cortex above it)
Abnormally persistent foci of embryonal immature blastema located in the superficial cortical region (perilobar)

trans-unit.target: Carcinoma papilar de células renales de tipo 1

trans-unit.source: A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma that is characterized by small cuboidal cells covering thin papillae with a single line of uniform nuclei and small nucleoli
A renal tumor originating from an oncocyte, which is an epithelial cell characterized by an excessive amount of mitochondria, resulting in an abundant acidophilic, granular cytoplasm

trans-unit.target: Retrusión del tercio medio de la cara

trans-unit.source: Posterior positions and/or vertical shortening of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased concavity of the face and/or reduced nasolabial angle

trans-unit.target: Aumento del tamaño de la glándula parótida

trans-unit.source: Increased size of the parotid gland
A benign (noncancerous) tumorlike malformation made up of an abnormal mixture of cells and tissues that originates in the tongue
Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal bridge, ridge and tip
A functional abnormality of a skeletal muscle
A structural abnormality of a skeletal muscle
Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 1 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy
Decreased intensity of the patellar reflex (also known as the knee jerk reflex)
A type of myotonia that worsens with repeated muscle contractions

trans-unit.target: Disminución de la habilidad para discriminar dos puntos

trans-unit.source: A reduced ability to distinguish tactile sensations at points that are very close to one another. This can be tested by using special calipers whose points can be set from 2mm to several centimeters apart

trans-unit.target: Deterioro para localizar el lugar donde han tocado a la persona

trans-unit.source: A reduced ability to identify precisely the site of a touch. This test is usually carried out by asking a patient, whose eyes are closed or covered, to touch the same site with a fingertip
Impaired ability to recognize letters or numbers drawn by an examiner's fingertip on the patient's skin (the patients eyes are closed or covered throughout this examination)

Lipofuscin (age pigment) is a brown-yellow, electron-dense, autofluorescent material that accumulates progressively over time in lysosomes of postmitotic cells, such as neurons and cardiac myocytes. This term pertains if there is an increase in the accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient
An increased level of hypoxanthine in the urine

A congenital defect in the skull, whereby there is a protrusion of part of the cranial contents through a congenital defect in the cranium, usually covered with skin or mucous membrane. The term encephalocele refers to a subclass of these lesions in which brain tissue protrudes through the defect
An encephalocele located between bregma and lambda

Basal encephalocele is an encephalocele that occurs along the cribriform plate or through the sphenoid bone. The mass may appear in the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, epipharynx, sphenoid sinus, posterior orbit, or pterygopalatine fossa. The important distinction from other types is that no external tumor is visible except in those rare instances of herniations so large that they protrude through the mouth or nares
A cleft of the muscular (soft) portion of the palate that is covered by mucous membrane. Soft-palate submucous clefts are characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscle tissue
Absence of the normal opening of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture) as a result of an obstructing choanal membrane that may be thin and strandlike or thick and pluglike
An abnormality of one or more of the set of bones that make up the facial skeleton
Increased width of the midpoint of the mandible (mental protuberance) and overlying soft tissue
Horizontal crease or fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin, with the face at rest

trans-unit.target: Pliegue en forma de H en la barbilla

trans-unit.source: H-shaped crease in the fat pad of the chin
#Chin, H-Shaped Crease #Chin, H-shaped groove #H-shaped dimple of the chin

trans-unit.target: Filtro con forma de V invertida

trans-unit.source: Prominence of a triangular soft tissue area of the philtrum with the apex to the columella

trans-unit.target: Filtro con un rafe en línea media

trans-unit.source: Narrow ridge in the midline of the philtral groove
Absence of the usual parallel position of philtral ridges

trans-unit.target: Seno de la línea media del filtro

trans-unit.source: Pit in the midline of the philtral groove

Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the ridges of the philtrum
Nasal tip positioned to one side of the midline
Decrease in width of the nasal tip
#Nasal tip, narrow #Nasal tip, pinched #Pinched nasal tip
Positioning of the nasal tip inferior to the nasal base
A noninflammatory, progressive occlusion of the intracranial carotid arteries owing to the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the circle of Willis

trans-unit.target: Retraso en la osificación del astrágalo

trans-unit.source: Delayed maturation and calcification of the talus
Detectable but decreased IgA levels that are more than 2 standard deviations below normal age-adjusted means
Localized thickening and tightness of the skin of the fingers or toes

trans-unit.target: Alteración del número de células T

trans-unit.source: A deviation from the normal count of T cells

trans-unit.target: Alteración de la fisiología de las células T

trans-unit.source: A deviation from the normal count of T cells
A potentially lethal cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an extremely rapid, hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia (150-300 beats/min) with a large oscillating sine-wave appearance
An abnormality of the form, structure, or size of the skeletal system
An abnormality of the function of the skeletal system

trans-unit.target: Morfología anormal de los huesos de las extremidades

trans-unit.source: An abnormality of the appendicular skeletal system, consisting of the of the limbs, shoulder and pelvic girdles
A benign, painful, tumor of bone characterized by the formation of osteoid tissue, primitive bone and calcified tissue

trans-unit.target: Tumor de células gigantes del hueso

trans-unit.source: A bone tumor composed of cellular spindle-cell stroma containing scattered multinucleated giant cells resembling osteoclasts
Any anomaly in the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance
Accumulation of blood within the pericardial sac

Accumulation of chyle (the whitish fluid taken up by the lacteals in the intestine, consisting of an emulsion of lymph and triglyceride fat thatpasses into the veins by the thoracic duct) in the pericardium. Chylopericardium is generally caused by obstruction of or trauma to the thoracic duct
Accumulation of serous fluid (pale yellow and transparent fluid) in the pericardial sac
Accumulation of blood in the peritoneal cavity owing to internal hemorrhage
Abnormal accumulation of fluid leading to swelling of the pharynx
An appetite for and the persistent ingestion of non-food substances such as clay. In order to diagnose pica, this behavior must have persisted over a period of at least one month
A discrete mass of neoplastic monoclonal plasma cells either in the bone marrow or in an extramedullary location
